page.title: List of firsts in the Geographic North Pole

revision.comment: It was magnetic north pole
revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=April 2010}} This is a '''list of firsts in the [[Geographic North Pole]]'''.
* One of the first to reach the Geographic North Pole (disputed): there were two primary claimants, [[Frederick Cook]], and his two [[Inuit]] men, Aapilak and Ittukusuk, on April 21, 1908 and [[Robert Edwin Peary]], [[Matthew Henson]] and four Inuit men: [[Ootah]], [[Seegloo]], [[Egingway]], and [[Ooqueah]] on April 6, 1909. Peary and Henson's claim eventually won widespread acceptance, but now neither claim is widely accepted. * First to fly over the North Pole (disputed): On May 9, 1926, Americans [[Richard E. Byrd]] and pilot [[Floyd Bennett]] claimed a successful flight over the North Pole in a Fokker F-VII Tri-motor called the ''Josephine Ford''. Byrd took off from [[Spitsbergen]] and returned to the same airfield. His claim, widely accepted at first, has been challenged since. * First [[Polar route|transpolar]] flight over the North Pole: On May 12, three days after the Byrd flight, Norwegian [[Roald Amundsen]], his American sponsor [[Lincoln Ellsworth]] and the Italian aeronautic engineer [[Umberto Nobile]] flew over the Pole in the [[semi-rigid airship]] ''[[Norge (airship)|Norge]]'', designed and piloted by Nobile. The total crew was 16 men. The ''Norge'' began in [[Spitsbergen]] and flew to [[Alaska]]. * First [[Polar route|transpolar]] flight over the North Pole in an airplane: [[Valery Chkalov]] and two others flew a [[Tupolev ANT-25]] on June 18–20, 1937 from [[Moscow]] to [[Vancouver, Washington|Vancouver]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]].<ref>{{Cite book|title = Red Arctic : Polar Exploration and the Myth of the North in the Soviet Union, 1932-1939|last = McCannon|first = John|publisher = Oxford University Press|year = 1998|isbn = |location = New York|pages = 71|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=u1OyKDItM5wC&pg=PA71&lpg=PA71&dq=Chkalov+1937+polar+route&source=bl&ots=poZLe1uzZe&sig=YCmg5eNKIfdoMkKQyZd8MODQ0Vo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjgop3En8PJAhVHVj4KHcPmA3EQ6AEIKDAC#v=onepage&q=Chkalov%201937%20polar%20route&f=false}}</ref> * First [[Drifting ice station|North Pole ice station]]: [[North Pole-1]] ([[Soviet Union]]) was established at {{Coord|89|25|N|78|40|W|name=North Pole-1 (start)}} (about 20 kilometres (12 mi) from the North Pole) on May 21, 1937. The expedition members: oceanographer [[Pyotr Shirshov]], meteorologist [[Yevgeny Konstantinovich Fyodorov|Yevgeny Fyodorov]], radio operator [[Ernst Krenkel]], and the leader [[Ivan Papanin]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whoi.edu/page.do?pid=66677|title=North Pole Drifting Stations (1930s-1980s)|accessdate=2012-01-08|publisher=[[Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution]]|date=2011-08-17}}</ref> conducted scientific research at the station for the next 274 days. On February 19, 1938, the group was evacuated by the ice breakers ''[[Icebreaker Taymyr|Taimyr]]'' and ''Murman''. By that time the station drifted 2850 km (1,770 mi) and was approaching the eastern coast of Greenland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.science20.com/chatter_box/arctic_heroes_2_north_pole_1 |title=Arctic Heroes #2 - North Pole 1|accessdate=2012-01-08|last=Lockerby|first= Patrick |date=2010-07-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/russiansinthearc006180mbp|title=The Russians in the Arctic|accessdate=2012-01-08|last=Armstrong|first=Terence|year=2011|isbn=978-1-245-58209-4|publisher=Nabu Press}}</ref> * First landing at the North Pole and first (confirmed) to stand on North Pole : three planes of ''Sever-2'' expedition (Soviet Union) of 24 scientists and flight crew led by [[Aleksandr Kuznetsov (explorer)|Aleksandr Kuznetsov]]. Pilots: Ivan Cherevichnyy, Vitaly Maslennikov and Ilya Kotov. Cherevichnyy's plane was the first one to land<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PYdBH4dOOM4C&lpg=PA7&ots=hcB3tSAthd&dq=April%2023%2C%201948%20kuznetsov&hl=ru&pg=PA7#v=onepage&q=April%2023%2C%201948%20kuznetsov&f=false|title=Exploring polar frontiers: a historical encyclopedia|last=Mills|first=William James|year=2003|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-57607-422-0|accessdate=2012-01-09}}</ref> at 4:44pm ([[Moscow Time]], [[UTC+04:00]]) on April 23, 1948.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.spri.cam.ac.uk/resources/infosheets/21.html|title = Concise chronology of approach to the poles|date = February 2001|publisher = [[Scott Polar Research Institute]] (SPRI)|accessdate = 2012-01-09}}</ref> * First people to parachute onto the North Pole: Vitaly Volovich and Andrei Medvedev (Soviet Union)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdfai.org/PDF/The%20Cold%20War%20in%20the%20Arctic.pdf |title=The Cold War in the Arctic |date=2010-07-29 |last=Barlow |first=John Matthew |publisher=[[Canadian Defence and Foreign Affairs Institute]] (CDFAI) |accessdate=2012-01-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605124121/http://www.cdfai.org/PDF/The%20Cold%20War%20in%20the%20Arctic.pdf |archivedate=2013-06-05 |df= }}</ref> on May 9, 1949,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skypole.ru/about/volovitch_e.htm |title=Vitaly Georgievich Volovich profile at |publisher=Polar World |accessdate=2012-01-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218040102/http://www.skypole.ru/about/volovitch_e.htm |archivedate=2008-12-18 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.century-of-flight.net/Aviation%20history/pathfinders/Arctic%20Aerial%20Exploration.htm |title=Arctic Aerial Exploration|accessdate=2012-01-09}}</ref> from [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain]], registered CCCP H-369.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc/1211994 |title=Десантников отправят на Северный полюс|date=2009-07-29|last=Сафронов-мл.|first=Иван |publisher=[[Kommersant|Коммерсантъ]]|accessdate=2012-01-09}}</ref> * First naval vessel to reach North Pole: the {{USS|Nautilus|SSN-571|6}}. August 3, 1958 * First (confirmed) to reach North Pole by surface travel (with [[Bombardier Recreational Products#Development of the small snowmobile|skidoo]]): [[Ralph Plaisted]]. April 19, 1968 * First (confirmed) to reach the North Pole by [[dogsled]]: team led by Sir [[Wally Herbert]]. 1968-69 * First [[surface ship]] to reach the North Pole: [[nuclear-powered icebreaker]] [[Arktika (1972 nuclear icebreaker)|''Arktika'']] (Soviet Union). August 17, 1977 * First people to ski from the continent to the North Pole: Expedition of [[Dmitry Shparo]], Jury Khmelevsky, Vladimir Ledenev, Anatoly Melnikov, Vladimir Rakmanov, Vasily Shishkarev and Vadim Davydov (Soviet Union). March 16-May 31, 1979 * First (confirmed) expedition to reach the North Pole without resupply (one-way trip, flew home from pole): [[Will Steger]] International Polar Expedition. May 1, 1986. The team members were: Paul Schurke, Brent Boddy, [[Richard Weber (explorer)|Richard Weber]], Geoff Carroll, [[Ann Bancroft]] and a team of 21 dogs. Brent Boddy & [[Richard Weber (explorer)|Richard Weber]] became the first Canadians to reach the North Pole on foot while [[Ann Bancroft]] became the first woman to trek to the Pole.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=North to the Pole|first=Will|last=Steger|magazine=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]|pp=288–317|volume=170|issue=3|date=September 1986|issn=0027-9358|oclc=643483454}}</ref> * First helicopter flight, by Australian [[Dick Smith (entrepreneur)|Dick Smith]] on 28 April 1987 in Bell Jetranger II VH-DIK.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Canberra Times|date=30 April 1987|title=Smith's Copter over N Pole}}</ref> * First surface crossing of the [[Arctic Ocean]] on skis: Soviet-Canadian Polar Bridge expedition, 1988, from Northern [[Siberia]] to [[Quttinirpaaq National Park|Ellesmere Island National Park Reserve]] in Canada, via the North Pole. Team members: 9 Soviets (Dmitry Shparo, Mikhail Malakhov, Vladimir Ledenov, Yury Khemeleski, Vasily Shishkariov, Alexandr Beliaev, Anatoly Melnikhov) and 4 Canadians (Richard Weber, Christopher Holloway, Max Buxton, Laurie Dexter). [[Richard Weber (explorer)|Richard Weber]] (Canadian team leader) became the first person to reach the North Pole from both sides of the Arctic Ocean. * First journey to the North Pole using only human resources: 1989 Vladimir Chukov «Arctica-89» Expedition. No dogs, air planes, or re-supplies. They departed [[Arctic Cape]] on March 15 and only seven of 13 people reached the Pole on May 6. One died 150 km before Pole, five were deported halfway.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ec-arctic.ru/forum/all_1/tag_167_1/topic_730/|title=Встреча полярников|accessdate=2015-01-30}}</ref> * First attempt to journey to the North Pole and return using only human resources: 1992 Weber Malakhov Expedition. [[Richard Weber (explorer)|Richard Weber]] and Mikhail (Misha) Malakhov departed from [[Ward Hunt Ice Shelf|Ward Hunt]] on March 13. Eighty-five days later, on June 14, they reached 89 degrees 39. With only 39 kilometers short of the Pole, they had to make the decision to turn back if they wanted to have any hope of returning to Ward Hunt. On June 21, due to the lack of ice, they were picked up by an airplane and brought back to safety. * First commercial North Pole expedition: Weber Malakhov North Pole Dash.1993 [[Richard Weber (explorer)|Richard Weber]] and Dr. Mikhail Malakhov pioneered the first commercial North Pole expedition. Today numerous companies take more than 100 people annually to the Pole. * First journey to the North Pole using only human resources by a single person: 1994 [[Børge Ousland]] expedition. No outside help, no dogs, air planes, or re-supplies. He departed [[Arctic Cape]] on March 2 and reached the Pole skiing.<ref name="arctica-94"/><ref name="arctica-94-2"/> * First journey to the North Pole using only human resources by starting command: 1994 Vladimir Chukov «Arctica-94» Expedition. No outside help, no dogs, air planes, or re-supplies. They departed [[Arctic Cape]] on March 15 and reached the Pole on May 17, by the same starting command of eight skiers.<ref name="arctica-94">{{cite web|url=http://www.ec-arctic.ru/forum/all_1/tag_167_1/topic_735/|title=17 мая 1994 года - впервые в мире Северный полюс успешно достигнут командой лыжников без внешней поддержки|accessdate=2015-01-30}}</ref><ref name="arctica-94-2">{{cite web|url=http://www.vokrugsveta.ru/vs/article/1148/|last=Chukov|first=Vladimir|title=Снова на полюс|date=May 1995|publisher=Vokrug Sveta|accessdate=2015-01-30}}</ref> * First journey to the North Pole and return using only human resources: 1995 Weber Malakhov Expedition. [[Richard Weber (explorer)|Richard Weber]] and Dr. Mikhail (Misha) Malakhov became the first to reach the North Pole and return to their starting point on land ([[Ward Hunt Ice Shelf|Ward Hunt]], Canada), with no outside help, no dogs, air planes, or re-supplies. They departed Ward Hunt on February 14 and reached the Pole eighty one days later, on May 12. On June 15, they were back at Ward Hunt establishing a record of 108 days for the longest unsupported polar journey. They are the only people to have reached the Pole four times. * First [[Scuba diving|scuba dive]] at the North Pole: Andrei Rozhkov (Russia) on April 22, 1998 (ended up in fatality).<ref name="scuba">{{cite web|url=http://www.divernetxtra.com/technol/0200northpole.htm|last=Cormick|first=Brett|title=Diving the top of the world|date=February 2000|publisher=Diver|accessdate=2012-01-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324132821/http://www.divernetxtra.com/technol/0200northpole.htm|archivedate=2012-03-24|df=}}</ref> * First successful scuba dive at the North Pole: Michael Wolff (Austria), Brett Cormick (UK) and Bob Wass (USA) on April 24, 1999<ref name="scuba"/> * First unsupported ski crossing of the Arctic Ocean: Rune Gjeldnes and Torry Larsen, in 109 days; they passed through the North Pole on April 29, 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norway.org/ARCHIVE/News/archive/2003/200303gjeldnes|title=No longer on thin ice|accessdate=2013-08-03}}</ref> * First unsupported solo trek from Canada to the North Pole: [[Pen Hadow]] reached the Pole May 19, 2003.<ref name = times030520>{{cite news| url = https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/pen-hadow-makes-history-by-walking-solo-to-the-north-pole-3smvnqxngt5 | title = Pen Hadow makes history by walking solo to the North Pole | publisher =The Times | date = May 20, 2003| first1 = Ginny| last1 = Dougary }}</ref> * First persons to reach the North Pole during the Arctic winter: [[Børge Ousland]] and [[Mike Horn]]. March 23, 2006 * First expedition to reach the North Pole on [[snowshoe]]s exclusively: April 26, 2006 North Pole Classic. [[Richard Weber (explorer)|Richard Weber]] guided Conrad Dickinson to the North Pole with no re-supplies. This was Richard Weber's fifth full North Pole expedition. He has trekked to the North Pole more than anyone in history. * On 21 February 2007 HRH Prince Edward announced the first British Army Expedition the Geographic North Pole, to be led by [[Captain Andrew Cooney]] (the youngest person to walk to the South Pole (see [http://www.northpole08.com])). *First to dive to geographic North Pole sea bottom: [[Arktika 2007]] expedition on August 2, 2007, by two [[MIR submarine]]s. Crew members were: [[Arthur Chilingarov]], [[Anatoly Sagalevich]] and [[Vladimir Gruzdev]] on MIR-1; Yevgeny Chernyaev, Mike McDowell and Frederik Paulsen on MIR-2.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Firsts in the Geographic North Pole}} [[Category:Exploration of the Arctic]] [[Category:Number-related lists]] [[Category:Geography-related lists|North Pole]] [[Category:Lists of firsts|Geographic North Pole]] [[Category:Arctic-related lists]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/2607:FEA8:A29F:F5E8:6CA1:FD80:1A27:8D7|2607:FEA8:A29F:F5E8:6CA1:FD80:1A27:8D7]] identified as test/vandalism using [[WP:STiki|STiki]]
revision.text:
'''Types of natural phenomena''' include:
[[Weather]], [[fog]], [[thunder]], [[tornado]]es; [[biological process]]es, [[decomposition]], [[germination]]; [[physical process]]es, [[wave propagation]], [[erosion]]; [[Tide|tidal flow]], and [[natural disasters]] such as [[electromagnetic pulse]]s, [[volcanic eruption]]s, and [[earthquake]]s.<ref>{{cite book |author1= Missy Allen |author2=Michel Peissel |year=1993 |title= Dangerous Natural Phenomena |url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=079101794X |publisher= [[Chelsea House]] |isbn= 079101794X}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author= William R. Corliss |year=1977 |title= Handbook of unusual natural phenomena |url= https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0915554011 |publisher= Sourcebook Project |isbn= 0915554011}}</ref>
==Biological== [[Image:DecayingPeachSmall.gif|frame|right|[Decomposition]: a decaying peach over a period of six days. Each frame is approximately 12 hours apart, as the fruit shrivels and becomes covered with [[mold]].]] * [[Decomposition]] – by which organic substances are broken down into a much simpler form of matter * [[Metabolism]] ** [[Catabolism]] ** [[Anabolism]] ** [[Fermentation]] – converts [[sugar]] to acids, gases and/or [[alcohol]]. * [[Cell growth|Growth]] * [[Population decrease]] ** [[Overpopulation]] growth beyond
== Chemical == [[File:Crystal in VCGS furnace.jpg|thumb|Crystal in VCGS furnace]] * [[Crystal growth]] * [[Oxidation]] ** [[Fire]] ** [[Rusting]]
== Geological == {{see also|List of geological phenomena}} [[File:Pahoeoe fountain edit2.jpg|thumb|Geology: [[parabola]]-shaped [[lava flow]] illustrates [[Galileo]]'s [[law of falling bodies]], as well as [[blackbody radiation]]. The [[temperature]] can be discerned from the color of the [[blackbody]].]] [[Geology|Geological]] processes include [[erosion]], [[sedimentation]], and [[Volcanism|volcanic activities]] such as geysers and [[earthquake]]s.
== Meteorological == {{see also|Atmospheric phenomenon|List of meteorological phenomena|List of severe weather phenomena}}
Violent [[Meteorology|meteorological]] phenomena are called [[storm]]s. Regular, cyclical phenomena include [[season]]s and [[atmospheric circulation]]. [[Climate change]] is often semi-regular.
<gallery class="center" widths="230px" heights="145px"> File:Galunggung.jpg|[[Lightning]] strikes during the eruption of the [[Galunggung]] [[volcano]] in 1982 File:Dszpics1.jpg|A [[tornado]] on May 3, 1999 in central Oklahoma </gallery>
===Atmospheric optical phenomena=== {{see also|Optical phenomena}} {{multiple image | width = thumb | footer = Atmospheric optical phenomenon | image1 = Double Bows.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = A double rainbow at Minsi Lake, Pennsylvania | image2 = Bretagne Finistere Plouhinec 05002.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 = A [[sun pillar]] in [[Finistère]], [[Brittany]] }} {{col-start}} {{col-2}} * [[Aurora]] * [[Crepuscular rays]] * [[Green flash]] * [[Haze]] * [[Ice blink]] * [[Light pillar]] * [[Moonbow]] {{col-2}} * [[Moon dog]] * [[Rainbow]] * [[Subsun]] * [[Sun dog]] * [[Water sky]] * [[Monochrome Rainbow]] {{col-end}}
=== Nuclear and Electrical === * [[Elementary particle]] interactions * [[Supernova]] <gallery class="center" caption="" widths="160px" heights="200px"> File:Liquid hydrogen bubble chamber photograph of an anti-proton colliding with a proton.jpg|Liquid hydrogen bubble chamber photograph of an anti-proton colliding with a proton File:Static on the playground (48616367).jpg|Children notice an effect of static electricity File:STScl-2005-15.png|Supernova </gallery>
===Oceanographic=== [[File:Golfstrom.jpg|thumb|Gulfstream]] * [[Oceanography|Oceanographic]] phenomena include [[tsunami]]s, [[ocean current]]s and [[breaking wave]]s.
== Physical == * [[Gravity]]
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Act of God]] * [[Electrical phenomena]] * [[Template:Life timeline|Life timeline]] * [[Materialism]] * [[Midnight sun]] * [[Natural environment]] * [[Nature]] * [[Template:Nature timeline|Nature timeline]] * [[Transient lunar phenomenon]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{commons category|Natural phenomena}} {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Portal bar|Ecology|Environment}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Natural phenomena}} [[Category:Atmospheric optical phenomena]] [[Category:Earth phenomena]] [[Category:Geography terminology]] [[Category:Nature-related lists]]

page.title: List of presidential trips made by Barack Obama during 2014

revision.comment: /* June */
revision.text:
{{main|Presidency of Barack Obama}} [[File:Barack Obama and Shinzo Abe at Sukyabashi Jiro April 2014.jpg|thumb|Obama dining with Japanese Prime Minister [[Shinzō Abe]] at [[Sukiyabashi Jiro]] during his visit to [[Tokyo]], Japan, April 23, 2014]] This is a '''list of presidential trips made by [[Barack Obama]] during 2014''', the sixth year of [[Presidency of Barack Obama|his presidency]] as the [[List of Presidents of the United States|44th]] [[President of the United States]]. This list excludes trips made within [[Washington, D.C.]], the U.S. federal capital in which the [[White House]], the official residence and principal workplace of the President, is located. Additionally excluded are trips to [[Camp David]], the country residence of the President, and to the private home of the [[Family of Barack Obama|Obama family]] in [[Kenwood, Chicago|Kenwood]], [[Chicago]]. ==January== {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! width=100|Country/
''U.S. state'' ! width=100|Areas visited ! width=60|Date(s) ! width=550|Details |- |{{Flagicon|North Carolina}} ''[[North Carolina]]'' |[[Raleigh, North Carolina|Raleigh]] |January 15 |President Obama toured [[Vacon]] facilities and delivered remarks at the [[North Carolina State University]], regarding manufacturing jobs.{{cite web|last1=Slack|first1=Megan|title=North Carolina Is Home to America’s Newest High-Tech Manufacturing Hub|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2014/01/15/north-carolina-home-america-s-newest-high-tech-manufacturing-hub|website=[[WhiteHouse.gov]]|accessdate=March 28, 2015|date=January 15, 2014}}{{cite news|title=President Obama announces new Raleigh-based manufacturing institute during North Carolina visit|url=http://abc11.com/politics/obama-unveils-plan-for-nc-innovation-hub/34877/|accessdate=March 28, 2015|publisher=[[WTVD]]|date=January 15, 2014}} |- |{{Flagicon|Pennsylvania}} ''[[Pennsylvania]]'' |[[Pittsburgh]] |January 29 |President Obama signed the [[myRA|''my''RA]] program and delivered remarks at [[U.S. Steel]]'s [[Mon Valley Works–Irvin Plant|Irvin plant]].{{cite news|last1=O'Toole|first1=James|title=President Obama delivers speech in West Mifflin|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/local/south/2014/01/29/President-Obama-land-in-Pittsburgh-headed-to-West-Mifflin/stories/201401290121|accessdate=March 28, 2015|publisher=''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]''|date=January 29, 2014}} |- |{{Flagicon|Wisconsin}} ''[[Wisconsin]]'' |[[Milwaukee]] |January 30 |President Obama visited [[General Electric]]'s Gas Engine Plant, where he delivered a speech regarding jobs and minimum wage.{{cite news|title=UPDATE: President Obama stops in Waukesha|url=http://www.nbc15.com/news/headlines/Pres-Obama-to-visit-Wisconsin-after-address-242242731.html|accessdate=March 28, 2015|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[WMTV]]|date=January 30, 2014}} |- |{{Flagicon|Tennessee}} ''[[Tennessee]]'' |[[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] |January 30 |President Obama delivered a speech on education at [[McGavock High School]].{{cite news|last1=Gang|first1=Duane W.|title=Obama pushes education in Nashville|url=http://archive.tennessean.com/article/20140130/NEWS/301300140/Obama-pushes-education-Nashville|accessdate=March 28, 2014|publisher=''[[The Tennessean]]''|date=January 30, 2014}} |} ==February== {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! width=100|Country/
''U.S. state'' ! width=100|Areas visited ! width=60|Date(s) ! width=550|Details |- |{{flagicon|Michigan}} ''[[Michigan]]'' |[[Lansing, Michigan|Lansing]],
[[East Lansing, Michigan|East Lansing]] |February 7 |President Obama toured the Michigan Biotechnology Institute in Lansing and signed the [[Agricultural Act of 2014]] at the [[Michigan State University]] in East Lansing.{{cite news|last1=Pickler|first1=Nedra|title=Obama signs farm bill that trims food stamps|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-2553724/Obama-signs-farm-bill-trims-food-stamps.html|accessdate=March 28, 2015|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=''[[Daily Mail]]''|date=February 7, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Virginia}} ''[[Virginia]]'' |[[Charlottesville, Virginia|Charlottesville]] |February 10 |President Obama took [[President of France|French President]] [[François Hollande]] on a trip to [[Monticello]], the residence of third President and [[Founding Fathers of the United States|Founding Father]] [[Thomas Jefferson]], who had served as a [[United States Ambassador to France|United States Minister to France]].{{cite news|last1=McCarthy|first1=Tom|title=Obama hosts French president François Hollande on state visit|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/feb/10/obama-french-president-francois-hollande-live|accessdate=March 28, 2015|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=February 10, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Maryland}} ''[[Maryland]]'' |[[Cambridge, Maryland|Cambridge]] |February 14 |President Obama spoke about [[Minimum wage in the United States|minimum wage]] increase and [[Immigration to the United States|immigration]] at the [[Democratic Caucus of the United States House of Representatives|House Democratic]] Issues Conference.{{cite news|last1=Babington|first1=Charles|title=Minimum wage increase, immigration overhaul top Obama’s agenda|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/minimum-wage-increases-immigration-overhaul-top-obamas-agenda/|accessdate=March 28, 2015|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=''[[PBS NewsHour]]''|date=February 15, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|California}} ''[[California]]'' |[[Fresno, California|Fresno]],
[[Palm Springs, California|Palm Springs]] |February 14–17 |In Fresno, President Obama met with community leaders during a [[Round table (discussion)|round table discussion]] to discuss the [[2012–15 North American drought]], before meeting with farmers affected by the drought, where he announced a $183 million aid for drought relief programs in California.{{cite news|last1=Onishi|first1=Norimitsu|last2=Davenport|first2=Coral|title=Obama Announces Aid for Drought-Stricken California|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/15/us/politics/obama-to-announce-aid-for-drought-racked-california.html?_r=0|accessdate=March 28, 2015|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=February The President also met with [[G7]] leaders at the [[Catshuis]] to discuss the [[Ukrainian crisis]] and met with [[Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands|King Willem-Alexander]] at the [[Royal Palace of Amsterdam]].{{cite news|last1=Sweet|first1=Lynn|title=Obama guidance & press schedule, March 24, 2014: The Netherlands|url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/7/71/168143/obama-guidance-press-schedule-march-24-2014-the-netherlands|accessdate=March 29, 2015|publisher=''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''|date=March 24, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Zeke J.|title=Obama Tries to Reassure Jittery Allies on Foreign Trip|url=http://time.com/34889/obama-trip-pope-francis/|accessdate=March 29, 2015|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''|date=March 23, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Belgium}} [[Belgium]] |[[Waregem]],

President Obama also delivered a speech at the [[Centre for Fine Arts, Brussels|Centre for Fine Arts]], mainly regarding the [[2014 Crimean crisis]].{{cite news|title=Obama lashes out at Russia over Crimea during Brussels speech|url=http://rt.com/usa/obama-brussels-nato-crimea-469/|accessdate=March 30, 2015|publisher=[[RT (TV network)|RT]]|date=March 26, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Cendrowics|first1=Leo|title=Barack Obama's first visit to Brussels to cost Belgium more than €10m|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/24/barack-obama-visit-brussels-cost-belgium-10m|accessdate=March 30, 2015|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=March 24, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Italy}} [[Italy]]

Robot|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/innovation/obama-gets-kick-out-soccer-playing-asimo-robot-n88631|accessdate=March 29, 2015|publisher=[[NBC News]]|date=April 24, 2014}} before attending a [[state Korea]] |[[Seoul]] |April 25–26 |President Obama attended a wreath-laying ceremony at the [[War Memorial of Korea]] and visited [[Gyeongbokgung]], before meeting with [[President of South Korea|President]] [[Park Geun-hye]] at the [[Blue House]] to discuss [[North Korea]]'s [[Nuclear power in North Korea|nuclear threat]] and the U.S.-Korea Free Trade Agreement. In the wake of the [[Sinking of the MV Sewol|sinking]] of the [[MV Sewol|MV ''Sewol'']], President Obama also presented President Park with the [[Flag of the United States|American flag]] that flew over the White House during the day of the disaster (April 16), as well as presenting a [[magnolia]] seed to the [[Danwon High School]], which victimized a number of the high school's students and teachers. The following day, the President met with American and Korean business leaders to discuss the trade and economic cooperation between the two countries and delivered remarks at [[Yongsan Garrison]].{{cite web|last1=Kim|first1=Ellen|title=President Obama’s Visit to South Korea|url=http://cogitasia.com/president-obamas-visit-to-south-korea/|publisher=[[Center for Strategic and International Studies]]|accessdate=March 29, 2015|date=April 29, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Landler|first1=Mark|title=Obama Offers Support to South Korea at a Moment of Trauma and Tension|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/26/world/asia/obama-asia.html?_r=0|accessdate=March 29, 2015|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=April 25, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Malaysia]] |[[Kuala Lumpur]] |April 26–28 |President Obama was greeted with a welcoming ceremony outside the [[Malaysian Houses of Parliament]], where he was accompanied by [[Yang di-Pertuan Agong]] [[Abdul Halim of Kedah|Abdul Halim]] and [[Prime Minister of Malaysia|Prime Minister]] [[Najib Razak]].{{cite news|title=As Obama arrives, Zaid slams Putrajaya’s inability to say hudud is unacceptable|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/as-obama-arrives-zaid-slams-putrajayas-inability-to-say-hudud-is-unacceptab|accessdate=March 30, 2015|publisher=''[[The Malay Mail]]''|date=April 26, 2014}} In the evening, the President was also hosted a state dinner by Yang di-Pertuan Agong Abdul Halim and [[Raja Permaisuri Agong]] [[Sultanah Haminah Hamidun]] at the [[Istana Negara, Jalan Duta|Istana Negara]].{{cite news|last1=Superville|first1=Darlene|title=Royal welcome for Obama on historic Malaysia trip|url=http://www.theoaklandpress.com/general-news/20140426/royal-welcome-for-obama-on-historic-malaysia-trip|accessdate=March 30, 2015|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=''[[The Oakland Press]]''|date=April 26, 2014}} On April 27, President Obama visited the [[National Mosque of Malaysia]], before holding a bilateral meeting and a joint press conference with Prime Minister Najib at the [[Perdana Putra]] to discuss issues on trade, defense, and maritime security, as well as the United States' commitment to contributing to the [[Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370|search]] for [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 370]].{{cite news|title=Obama says US committed to providing assets for MH370 ocean search|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/obama-says-us-committed-to-providing-assets-for-mh370-ocean-search|accessdate=March 30, 2015|publisher=''[[The Malay Mail]]''|date=April 27, 2014}} He also delivered remarks at the [[Malaysian Global Innovation and Creativity Centre]] and participated in the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative Town Hall meeting at the [[University of Malaya]]. |- |{{flagicon|Philippines}} [[Philippines]] |[[Manila]],

followed by a joint press conference.{{cite web|title=Remarks by President Obama and President Benigno Aquino III of the Philippines in Joint Press Conference|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/04/28/remarks-president-obama-and-president-benigno-aquino-iii-philippines-joi|website=[[WhiteHouse.gov]]|accessdate=March 30, Philippines|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2014/04/29/1317422/obama-us-committed-defend-philippines|accessdate=March 30, 2015|publisher=''[[The Philippine Star]]''|date=April 29, 2014}} and [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] |May 7–9 |In Los Angeles, President Obama attended a joint event for the [[Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee]] and [[Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee]], before attending a fundraising gala for the [[USC Shoah Foundation Institute for Visual History and Education]], where he was awarded an Ambassador for Humanity Award by founder [[Steven Spielberg]].{{cite news|last1=Sweet|first1=Lynn|title=Obama guidance & press schedule May 7, 2014 Arkansas, Los Angeles|url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/7/71/166304/obama-guidance-press-schedule-may-7-2014-arkansas-los-angeles|accessdate=March 30, 2015|publisher=''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''|date=May 7, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Cohen|first1=Sandy|title=Obama hangs with Spielberg, Springsteen at benefit|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2014/may/07/obama-hangs-with-spielberg-springsteen-at-benefit/|accessdate=March 30, 2015|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=''[[U-T San Diego]]''|date=May 7, 2014}} The President then flew to San Diego to attend a fundraising event at the residence of [[Qualcomm]] co-founder [[Irwin M. on the [[Military intervention against the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|military intervention]] against the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]].{{cite news|last1=Acosta|first1=Jim|last2=Liptak|first2=Kevin|last3=Levs|first3=Josh|title=Obama, Kerry: No U.S. troops will be sent into combat against ISIS in Iraq, Syria|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/09/17/politics/obama-isis/|accessdate=April 2, 2015|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=September 17, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|New York}} ''[[New York (state)|New York]]'' |[[New York City]] |September 23–25 |President Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama visited the [[Headquarters of the United Nations|headquarters]] of the [[United Nations]], where the President spoke at the [[Climate Summit]] and at the [[sixty-ninth session of the United Nations General Assembly]].{{cite news|last1=Volcovici|first1=Valerie|title=Obama says global climate deal must include emerging economies|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/23/us-un-climatechange-obama-idUSKCN0HI23G20140923|accessdate=April 2, 2015|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=September 23, 2014}}{{cite web|title=Remarks by President Obama in Address to the United Nations General Assembly|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/09/24/remarks-president-obama-address-united-nations-general-assembly|website=[[WhiteHouse.gov]]|accessdate=April 2, 2015|date=September 24, 2014}} The President also delivered remarks at the [[Clinton Foundation#Clinton Global Initiative (CGI)|Clinton Global Initiative]],{{cite web|title=Remarks by the President at Clinton Global Initiative|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/09/23/remarks-president-clinton-global-initiative|website=[[WhiteHouse.gov]]|accessdate=April 2, 2015|date=September 23, 2014}} attended a Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee fundraising event,{{cite news|last1=Sweet|first1=Lynn|title=Obama guidance, schedule, Sept. 23, 2014 — Syria strikes, to UN|url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/7/71/155243/obama-guidance-schedule-sept-23-2014-syria-strikes-to-un|accessdate=April 2, 2015|publisher=''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''|date=September 23, 2014}} presided the [[United Nations Security Council]] meeting to discuss a resolution against [[terrorism]],{{cite web|title=U.N. Security Council Meeting on Terrorism|url=http://www.c-span.org/video/?321668-1/president-obama-chairs-un-security-council-meeting-isis|publisher=[[C-SPAN]]|accessdate=April 2, 2015|date=September 24, 2014}} spoke at an [[Open Government Partnership]] event,{{cite web|title=10 World Leaders Speaking at #OGPatUN|url=http://www.opengovpartnership.org/blog/open-government-partnership/2014/09/17/10-world-leaders-speaking-ogpatun|publisher=[[Open Government Partnership]]|accessdate=April 3, 2015|date=September 17, 2014}} and met with [[Iraq]]i [[Prime Minister of Iraq|Prime Minister]] [[Haider al-Abadi]],{{cite news|last1=Mohammed|first1=Arshad|title=Iraqi PM says Islamic State plans subway attacks in U.S. and Paris|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/25/us-iraq-crisis-attack-idUSKCN0HK20I20140925|accessdate=April 2, 2015|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=September 25, 2014}} [[Egypt]]ian [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]],{{cite news|title=Obama meets with el-Sissi, says Egypt key to Mideast security Read more: Obama meets with el-Sissi, says Egypt key to Mideast security|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/obama-meets-with-el-sissi-says-egypt-key-to-mideast-security/|accessdate=April 2, 2015|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=''[[The Times of Israel]]''|date=September 26, 2014}} and [[Ethiopia]]n [[Prime Minister of Ethiopia|Prime Minister]] [[Hailemariam Desalegn]].{{cite news|title=US President Barack Obama holds a bilateral meeting with Ethiopia's Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn in New York|url=http://www.siasat.com/photos/us-president-barack-obama-holds-bilateral-meeting-ethiopias-prime-minister-hailemariam-desal-0|accessdate=April 2, 2015|publisher=''[[The Siasat Daily]]''|date=September 26, 2014}} |} ==October== {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! width=100|Country/
''U.S. state'' ! width=100|Areas visited ! width=60|Date(s) ! width=550|Details |- |{{flagicon|Indiana}} ''[[Indiana]]''
{{flagicon|Illinois}} ''[[Illinois]]'' |[[Gary, Indiana|Gary]],
[[Chicago]] |October 1–2 |President Obama arrived at [[Gary/Chicago International Airport]] in Gary, Indiana,{{cite news|title=Gary mayor asks Obama for longer visit next time|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/oct/2/gary-mayor-asks-obama-for-longer-visit-next-time/|accessdate=April 3, 2015|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=''[[The Washington Times]]''|date=October 2, 2014}} where he proceeded to Chicago to attend a fundraising event for [[Governor of Illinois|Governor]] [[Pat Quinn (politician)|Pat Quinn]], before delivering a speech on the economy at [[Northwestern University]].{{cite news|title=President Obama To Visit Northwestern For Speech On The Economy|url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2014/10/02/president-obama-to-visit-northwestern-for-speech-on-the-economy/|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=[[CBS]]|date=October 2, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Indiana}} ''[[Indiana]]'' |[[Princeton, Indiana|Princeton]] |October 3 |President Obama visited the [http://www.millenniumsteelservice.com/ Millennium Steel Service] plant to deliver remarks on manufacturing and its effect on the economy.{{cite news|last1=Swiatek|first1=Jeff|title=President Obama touts strength of manufacturing in Indiana speech|url=http://www.indystar.com/story/money/2014/10/03/white-house-caller-surprised-southern-indiana-businessman/16612801/|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=''[[The Indianapolis Star]]''|date=October 3, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|New York}} ''[[New York (state)|New York]]'' |[[New York City]] |October 7 |President Obama attended two Democratic National Committee events.{{cite news|last1=Lederman|first1=Josh|title=Obama visits NYC, Conn. Tuesday|url=http://www.myfoxny.com/story/26721979/obama-visit-nyc|accessdate=April 3, 2015|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[WNYW]]|date=October 7, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Sweet|first1=Lynn|title=Obama guidance, schedule, Oct. 7, 2014: NYC for Dem fundraisers|url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/7/71/154709/obama-guidance-schedule-oct-7-2014-nyc-for-dem-fundraisers|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''|date=October 7, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Massachusetts}} ''[[Massachusetts]]'' |[[Greenwich, Massachusetts|Greenwich]] |October 7 |President Obama attended a fundraising event for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.{{cite news|last1=Vigdor|first1=Neil|title=Obama draws Democratic supporters in Greenwich|url=http://www.ctpost.com/local/article/Obama-draws-Democratic-supporters-in-Greenwich-5807942.php#page-1|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=''[[Connecticut Post]]''|date=October 8, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|California}} ''[[California]]'' |[[Los Angeles County]],
[[San Francisco]] |October 9–11 |President Obama attended a town hall meeting on the economy at [http://www.crosscamp.us/ Cross Campus] in [[Santa Monica, California|Santa Monica]] and a fundraising event for the Democratic National Committee at the residence of actress [[Gwyneth Paltrow]] in [[Brentwood, Los Angeles|Brentwood]].{{cite news|title=Obama Hails "Millennials" as Driving Force in Rebuilding Economy|url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/President-Barack-Obama-Fundraiser-Economic-Plan-Los-Angeles-Visit-Gwyneth-Paltrow-278692351.html|accessdate=April 3, 2015|agency=[[The Wire Report]]|publisher=[[KNBC]]|date=October 9, 2014}} The President also spoke at the [[Frank G. Bonelli Regional Park]] in [[San Dimas, California|San Dimas]] to declare [[San Gabriel Mountains National Monument|part]] of the [[San Gabriel Mountains]] a [[National Monument (United States)|National Monument]].{{cite news|title=President Obama declares part of San Gabriel Mountains a national monument|url=http://abc7.com/hobbies/president-obama-declares-part-of-san-gabriel-mountains-a-national-monument/345448/|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=[[KABC-TV]]|date=October 10, 2014}} In San Francisco, President Obama attended a round table discussion and a fundraising event for the Democratic National Committee at the residence of [[Zynga]] co-founder [[Mark Pincus]].{{cite news|title=President Obama Wraps Up San Francisco Fundraising Trip|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/President-Obama-in-San-Francisco-Friday-for-DNC-Fundraisers-278739871.html|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=[[KNTV]]|date=October 11, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Illinois}} ''[[Illinois]]'' |[[Chicago]] |October 19–20 |President Obama attended a campaign rally for Governor Pat Quinn at the [[Chicago State University]], as well as a Democratic National Committee fundraising event. The President also cast an [[Early voting|early vote]] for the [[United States elections, 2014|2014 midterm elections]].{{cite news|title=Obama Fires Up Democrats, Urges Early Voting For Quinn|url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2014/10/20/obama-fires-up-democrats-urges-early-voting-for-quinn/|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=[[CBS]]|date=October 20, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Wisconsin}} ''[[Wisconsin]]'' |[[Milwaukee]] |October 28 |President Obama delivered a speech at the campaign rally for [[Governor of Wisconsin|Governor]] [[Wisconsin gubernatorial election, 2014|candidate]] [[Mary Burke]] at the [[North Division High School (Milwaukee)|North Division High School]].{{cite news|last1=Newton-Small|first1=John|title=Obama Rallies Wisconsin Democrats for Mary Burke|url=http://time.com/3544687/barack-obama-mary-burke-governor-rally/|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''|date=October 29, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Maine}} ''[[Maine]]'' |[[Portland, Maine|Portland]],
[[Cape Elizabeth, Maine|Cape Elizabeth]] |October 30 |President Obama attended a fundraising event in Cape Elizabeth with [[United States House of Representatives|Representative]] [[Mike Michaud]], before attending a rally for Michaud's gubernatorial campaign at the [[Portland Exposition Building]].{{cite news|last1=Merrill|first1=Paul|title=President Obama visits Maine|url=http://www.wmtw.com/politics/obama-to-rally-for-michaud-in-portland/29426604|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=[[WMTW]]|date=October 30, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Rhode Island}} ''[[Rhode Island]]'' |[[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]] |October 30–31 |President Obama attended a round table discussion with faculty and students at [[Rhode Island College]], before delivering a speech regarding the economy and women.{{cite news|last1=McGee|first1=Sandy|title=Women, economy focus of President Obama RIC speech|url=http://wpri.com/2014/10/31/women-economy-focuse-of-president-obama-ric-speech/|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=[[WPRI-TV]]|date=November 1, 2014}} |} ==November== {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! width=100|Country/
''U.S. state'' ! width=100|Areas visited ! width=60|Date(s) ! width=550|Details |- |{{flagicon|Michigan}} ''[[Michigan]]'' |[[Detroit]] |November 1 |President Obama delivered a speech at the [[Wayne State University]] to campaign for [[United States Senator|Senator]] [[United States Senate election in Michigan, 2014|candidate]] [[Gary Peters (politician)|Gary Peters]] and [[Governor of Michigan|Governor]] [[Michigan gubernatorial election, 2014|candidate]] [[Mark Schauer]].{{cite news|title=Obama Rallies Wayne State Crowd To Vote For Schauer, Peters On Tuesday|url=http://detroit.cbslocal.com/2014/11/01/obama-rallies-wayne-state-crowd-to-vote-for-schauer-peters-on-tuesday/|accessdate=May 1, 2015|publisher=[[WWJ-TV]]|date=November 1, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|China}} [[China]] |[[Beijing]] |November 10–12 |President Obama attended the [[APEC China 2014|APEC summit]]. On November 11–12, the President held bilateral meetings with [[President of the People's Republic of China|President]] [[Xi Jinping]] to discuss [[China–United States relations]] and international and regional issues, as well as [[Comparison of US and Chinese Military Armed Forces|military relations]], the [[One-China policy]], [[climate change]], and terrorism.{{cite news|title=Xi, Obama walk and talk one-on-one in Beijing|url=http://www.cctv-america.com/2014/11/11/xi-obama-walk-and-talk-in-beijing-u-s-presidents-visit-to-china-continues-tomorrow|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=[[CCTV issues|url=http://www.cctv-america.com/2014/11/12/us-china-bilateral-talks-covers-several-major-issues|accessdate=April 3, 2015|agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|publisher=[[CCTV America]]|date=November negotiations|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/world/2014apec/2014-11/12/content_18904104.htm|accessdate=April 3, 2015|agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|publisher=''[[China Daily]]''|date=November 12, |{{flagicon|Burma}} [[Burma|Myanmar (Burma)]] |[[Naypyidaw]],
[[Yangon]] |November 12–14 |In Naypyidaw, President Obama attended the [[Ninth East Asia Summit|East Asia Summit]] and the U.S.-[[Association of Southeast Asian Nations|ASEAN]] summit meeting.{{cite news|last1=Lederman|first1=Josh|title=Obama returns to Myanmar as country struggles with democratic also held a bilateral meeting with [[Vietnam]]ese [[Prime Minister of Vietnam|Prime Minister]] [[Nguyễn Tấn Dũng]].{{cite news|title=Obama backs Suu Kyi bid to change constitution|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-2834271/Obama-backs-Suu-Kyi-bid-change-constitution.html|accessdate=April 3, 2015|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|publisher=''[[Daily Mail]]''|date=November 14, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Pace|first1=Julie|title=Myanmar troubles jeopardize a big Obama goal|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-2830996/Obama-confront-shortcomings-Myanmar-reforms.html|accessdate=April 3, 2015|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=''[[Daily Mail]]''|date=November 13, 2014}} The President attended a round table discussion with members of the [[Assembly of the Union]], Speaker [[Shwe Mann]] of the [[House of Representatives (Burma)|House of Representatives]], Speaker [[Khin Aung Myint]] of the [[House of Nationalities]], and [[Opposition (Myanmar)|Opposition]] Leader [[Aung San Suu Kyi]] to further discuss Burma's democratic reforms.{{cite web|title=Remarks by President Obama After Roundtable at Parliamentary Resource Center|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/11/13/remarks-president-obama-after-roundtable-parliamentary-resource-center-n|website=[[WhiteHouse.gov]]|accessdate=April 3, 2015|date=November 13, 2014}} In Yangon, President Obama held a bilateral meeting with Suu Kyi at [[54 University Avenue|her residence]], which was followed by a joint press conference,{{cite news|title=Barack Obama Holds Talks With Myanmar Democracy Champion Aung San Suu Kyi|url=http://www.ndtv.com/world-news/barack-obama-holds-talks-with-myanmar-democracy-champion-aung-san-suu-kyi-696954|accessdate=April 3, 2015|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|publisher=[[NDTV]]|date=November 14, 2014}} before participating in the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative Town Hall meeting at the [[University of Yangon]].{{cite web|title=Remarks by President Obama at Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative Town Hall, 11/14/14|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/11/14/remarks-president-obama-young-southeast-asian-leaders-initiative-town-ha|website=[[WhiteHouse.gov]]|accessdate=April 3, 2015|date=November 14, 2014}} Additionally, the President had toured the [[Ministers' Building]] and attended a round table discussion with [[civil society]] organizations at the [[Embassy of the United States, Rangoon|United States Embassy in Yangon]].{{cite news|author1=Kyaw Phyo Tha|title=Obama Visits Site of Burmese Independence in Rangoon|url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/multimedia-burma/obama-visits-site-burmese-independence-rangoon.html|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=''[[The Irrawaddy]]''|date=November 14, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403085030/http://www.irrawaddy.org/multimedia-burma/obama-visits-site-burmese-independence-rangoon.html|archivedate=April 3, 2015|df=}}{{cite web|title=Remarks by President Obama After Civil Society Roundtable|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/11/14/remarks-president-obama-after-civil-society-roundtable|website=[[WhiteHouse.gov]]|accessdate=April 3, 2015|date=November 14, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Australia}} [[Australia]] |[[Brisbane]] |November 15–16 |President Obama attended the [[2014 G20 Brisbane summit|G20 summit]] held at the [[Brisbane Convention & Exhibition Centre]].{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Lenore|title=G20: Barack Obama uses visit to reassert US influence in Asia Pacific|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/nov/15/g20-barack-obama-uses-visit-to-reassert-us-influence-in-asia-pacific|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=November 15, 2014}} The President also held a trilateral meeting with Prime Minister Tony Abbott and [[Japan]]ese [[Prime Minister of Japan|Prime Minister]] [[Shinzō Abe]] to discuss [[Russia]]'s [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexation]] of [[Crimea]] and delivered a speech at the [[University of Queensland]] regarding [[youth voice]].{{cite news|last1=Spetalnick|first1=Matt|last2=Siegel|first2=Matt|title=U.S., Japan and Australia vow to oppose Russian action in Crimea|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/11/16/us-g20-summit-trilateral-idUSKCN0J000L20141116|accessdate=April 3, 2015|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=November 15, 2014}}{{cite web|title=President Obama inspires students with landmark speech|url=http://www.uq.edu.au/news/article/2014/11/president-obama-inspires-students-landmark-speech|publisher=[[University of Queensland]]|accessdate=April 3, 2015|date=November 16, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Nevada}} ''[[Nevada]]'' |[[Las Vegas]] |November 21 |President Obama delivered a speech at the [[Del Sol High School]] to discuss his [[Immigration reform#Obama's executive actions of November 2014|executive plans for an immigration reform]].{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Brianna|title=Immigration: Obama Las Vegas Speech Pressures Congress, #PassABill Trends On Twitter|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/immigration-obama-las-vegas-speech-pressures-congress-passabill-trends-twitter-1727873|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=''[[International Business Times]]''|date=November 21, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Illinois}} ''[[Illinois]]'' |[[Chicago]] |November 25 |President Obama spoke at the [[Gateway Theatre (Chicago)|Mitchell P. Kobelinski Theater]] to promote his executive plans for an immigration reform.{{cite news|last1=Schulte|first1=Sarah|title=Pres. Obama in Chicago to talk immigration policies|url=http://abc7chicago.com/politics/pres-obama-in-chicago-to-talk-immigration-policies/411041/|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=[[WLS-TV]]|date=November 25, 2014}} |} ==December== {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! width=100|Country/
''U.S. state'' ! width=100|Areas visited ! width=60|Date(s) ! width=550|Details |- |{{flagicon|Maryland}} ''[[Maryland]]'' |[[Bethesda, Maryland|Bethesda]] |December 2 |President Obama met with injured troops at the [[Walter Reed National Military Medical Center]],{{cite news|last1=Sweet|first1=Lynn|title=Obama guidance, press schedule Dec. 2, 2014. Hagel, Ebola|url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/7/71/213947/obama-guidance-press-schedule-dec-2-2014-hagel-ebola|accessdate=April 3, 2015|publisher=''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''|date=December 2, 2014}} before touring the [[National Institutes of Health]], where he spoke on the efforts to fighting the [[Ebola virus epidemic in West Africa|Ebola virus epidemic]] in [[West Africa]].{{cite news|title=President Obama talks about Ebola at NIH|url=http://www.wusa9.com/story/news/health/2014/12/02/president-obama-nih-bethesda-md-visit-about-ebola/19771917/|accessdate=April 3, 2015|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[WUSA (TV)|WUSA]]|date=December 3, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Tennessee}} ''[[Tennessee]]'' |[[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] |December 9 |President Obama delivered remarks at [http://www.casaazafran.org/ Casa Azafrán] to discuss his executive plans for an immigration reform.{{cite news|last1=Zezima|first1=Katie|last2=Nakamura|first2=David|title=Obama takes pitch for immigration reform to Nashville|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/why-nashville-is-the-backdrop-for-obamas-immigration-pitch/2014/12/09/cfeaea10-7f71-11e4-9f38-95a187e4c1f7_story.html|accessdate=April 3, {| class="infobox bordered" style="width: 17em; text-align: left; font-size: 95%;" |+ style="font-size: larger;" | '''Local Notice to Mariners''' |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | [[Image:Local-notice-to-mariners-thumb.jpg|175px|]]
The first page of a Local Notice to Mariners. |- ! Purpose: | Provide corrections of a local nature to navigational publications and nautical charts. |- ! Publication Frequency: | Weekly |- ! Published by: | Local [[U.S. Coast Guard]] District |- ! Available Online: | Yes [http://www.navcen.uscg.gov/?pageName=lnmMain] |- |} A '''Local Notice to Mariners''' is an authoritative instruction issued by a designated official, typically the [[harbormaster]]. ==United States== In the United States, notices are issued by each [[U.S. Coast Guard]] District to disseminate important information affecting navigational safety within that District. This Notice reports changes and deficiencies in aids to navigation maintained by the Coast Guard. Other marine information such as new [[nautical chart|charts]], channel depths, naval operations, and regattas is included. Since temporary information of short duration is not included in the weekly [[Notice to Mariners]], the ''Local Notice to Mariners'' may be the only source of such information. Small craft using the [[Intracoastal Waterway]] and small harbors not normally used by oceangoing vessels need it to keep charts and publications up-to-date. Since correcting information for U.S. charts in the ''Notice to Mariners'' is obtained from the Coast Guard Local Notices, it is normal to expect a lag of 1 or 2 weeks for the ''Notice to Mariners'' to publish a correction from this source. The ''Local Notice to Mariners'' may be obtained free of charge by contacting the appropriate Coast Guard District Commander. Vessels operating in ports and waterways in several districts must obtain the ''Local Notice to Mariners'' from each district. ===Sources=== The text of the US material originated from section 422 of The [[American Practical Navigator]], a document produced by the government of the [[United States|United States of America]]. ==Examples== LNTMs are, by definition, concerned with local issues. Each issuing authority has its own series of LNTMs – there is no international standard numbering or indexing scheme. Individual LNTMs may concern short or long term situations. At [http://www.qhmportsmouth.com/port-lntm/ Portsmouth], mariners are instructed by LNTM 28/07 to ''keep clear of warship berths''. At [http://www.holyheadport.com/LNTM%20Index.pdf Holyhead], LNTM 5/2008 concerns ''Bunkering or transferring oil in port''. At [http://www.conservancy.co.uk/water/local_notices.asp Chichester], No 16 of 2008 ''Sea defence works at Hayling Island'' gives timely information about dredging operations. ==See also== {{Portal|Nautical}} *[[American Practical Navigator]] *[[Buoy]] *[[Coast Pilots]] *[[Light List]] *[[List of Lights]] *[[Notice to Mariners]] *[[Sailing Directions]] ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061016164246/http://www.irbs.com/bowditch/pdf/chapt04.pdf Chapter 4: Nautical Publications] - from the online edition of [[Nathaniel Bowditch]]'s ''American Practical Navigator'' * [http://www.navcen.uscg.gov/?pageName=lnmMain Local Notices to Mariners online] {{Navigation publications}} {{Works about sailing}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Local Notice To Mariners}} [[Category:Navigation]] [[Category:Hydrography]] [[Category:Sailing books]]

revision.comment: Disambiguated: [[ESRI]] → [[Environmental Systems Research Institute]]
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=February 2016}}
'''Location intelligence''' ('''LI'''), or '''spatial intelligence''', is the process of deriving meaningful insight from [[geographic data and information|geospatial data]] relationships to solve a particular problem.<ref>Data Resources For Real Estate And Business Geography Analysis. Thrall,G.,I.,Ph.D.(2009)/Professor, Department of Geography, College of Liberal Arts And Sciences and Miller Center For Retail, College of Business, University of Florida</ref> It involves layering multiple data sets spatially and/or chronologically, for easy reference on a map, and its applications span industries, categories and organizations.
Maps have been used to represent information throughout the ages, but what might be referenced as the first example of true location 'intelligence' was in London in 1854 when [[John Snow]] was able to debunk theories about the spread of cholera by overlaying a map of the area with the location of water pumps and was able to narrow the source to a single water pump. This layering of information over a map was able to identify relationships between different sets of geospatial data.
Location or [[geographical information system]] (GIS) tools enable spatial experts to collect, store, [[data analysis|analyze]] and [[data visualization|visualize data]]. Location intelligence experts can use a variety of spatial and business analytical tools to measure optimal locations for operating a business or providing a service. Location intelligence experts begin with defining the [[business ecosystem]] which has many interconnected economic influences. Such economic influences include but are not limited to culture, lifestyle, labor, healthcare, cost of living, crime, economic climate and education.
==Further definitions== The term "location intelligence" is often used to describe the people, data and technology employed to geographically "map" information. These mapping applications can transform large amounts of data into color-coded visual representations that make it easy to see trends and generate meaningful intelligence. The creation of location intelligence is directed by [[domain knowledge]], formal frameworks, and a focus on decision support. Location cuts across through everything i.e. devices, platforms, software and apps, and is one of the most important ingredient of understanding context in sync with social data, mobile data, user data, sensor data.
Location intelligence is also used to describe the integration of a geographical component into [[business intelligence]] processes and tools, often incorporating [[spatial database]] and spatial [[OLAP]] tools.
In 2012, Wayne Gearey from the [[real estate industry]] ([[JLL (company)|JLL]]) offered the first applied course on location intelligence at the University of Texas at Dallas in which he defined location intelligence as the process for selecting the optimal location that will support workplace success and address a variety of business and financial objectives.<ref name="RealViews 2015">{{cite web|url=https://www.jllrealviews.com/trends/why-location-intelligence-is-a-game-changer-for-the-property-industry/|title=Why location intelligence is a ‘game changer’ for real estate|last=Avery|first=Lois|date=2015-05-20|website=RealViews|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161019164338/https://www.jllrealviews.com/trends/why-location-intelligence-is-a-game-changer-for-the-property-industry/|archive-date=2016-10-19|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=W.M. Gearey, N.M.Trodd, A. Fobes|title=Utilizing Location Intelligence for the Placement of Corporate Services|url=http://www.gla.ac.uk/media/media_401758_en.pdf}}</ref>
[[Pitney Bowes]] MapInfo Corporation describes location intelligence as follows: "Spatial information, commonly known as "Location", relates to involving, or having the nature of where. Spatial is not constrained to a geographic location however most common business uses of spatial information deal with how spatial information is tied to a location on the earth. Miriam-Webster® defines Intelligence as "The ability to learn or understand, or the ability to apply knowledge to manipulate one`s environment." Combining these terms alludes to how you achieve an understanding of the spatial aspect of information and apply it to achieve a significant competitive advantage."<ref>{{cite web |author=George Moon |publisher=Pitney Bowes |url=http://www.pbinsight.com/files/resource-library/resource-files/LocationIntell_WP_2-27Final.pdf |format=PDF |language=en |title=Location Intelligence – Meeting IT Expectation |date=c. 2008 |access-date=2015-10-05}}</ref>
Definition by [[Environmental Systems Research Institute|ESRI]] is as follows: "Location Intelligence is defined as the capacity to organize and understand complex data through the use of geographic relationships. LI organizes business and geographically referenced data to reveal the relationship of location to people, events, transactions, facilities, and assets."<ref>{{cite web |author=ESRI |url=https://www.esri.com/~/media/files/pdfs/library/whitepapers/pdfs/using-location-intelligence.pdf |format=PDF |language=en |title=Using Location Intelligence to Maximize the Value of BI |access-date=2015-10-05}}</ref>
Definition by [[Yankee Group]] within their White Paper "Location Intelligence in Retail Banking: "...a business management term that refers to spatial data visualization, contextualization and analytical capabilities applied to solve a business problem."<ref>{{cite web |author=Marcus Torchia |publisher=Pitney Bowes |url=http://www.pbinsight.com/files/resource-library/resource-files/yankee-group.pdf |format=PDF |language=en |title=Location Intelligence in Retail Banking |date=c. 2009 |access-date=2015-10-05}}</ref>
[[Near (company)|Near]] defines location intelligence as the gamut of geo-spatial analytic models, algorithms, techniques and tools that harness location-indexed streaming and static data to provide requisite answers to questions around location such as the attributes of i) a place, ii) people visiting a place, and iii) products consumed at a place. Location intelligence platforms encapsulate these technologies, ingest relevant data sources, and provide it as data-as-a-service, or use it to power data-driven products.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mmaglobal.com/articles/location-intelligence-next-frontier |title= Location Intelligence: The Next Frontier|publisher=Mobile Marketing Association, Inc|date=May 3, 2016}}</ref>
Instarea defines location intelligence as "Using [[machine learning]] algorithms to uncover trends that would be otherwise unknown using human based rules in a large location data set."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gartner.com/doc/3795764|title=Market Trends: Ways CSPs Can Exploit Location Data|last=|first=|date=|website=Gartner.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref>
==Commercial applications==
Location intelligence is used by a broad range of industries to improve overall business results. Applications include: * [[Communications]] and [[telecommunications]]: [[Network planning and design]], boundary identification, identifying new customer markets. * [[Financial services]]: Optimize branch locations, market analysis, [[Share of Wallet|share of wallet]] and [[cross-sell]] activities, [[mergers & acquisitions]], industry sector analysis, risk management. * [[Government]]: Census updates, law enforcement crime analysis, emergency response, environmental and land management, electoral [[redistricting]], tax jurisdiction assignment, [[urban planning]]. * [[Healthcare]]: Site selection, [[market segmentation]], network analysis, growth assessments. * [[Higher education]]: Student Recruitment, Alumni & Donor Tracking, Campus Mapping. * [[Hotel]]s and [[restaurant]]s: Customer profile analysis, site selection, [[target marketing]], expansion planning. * [[Insurance]]: Address validation, underwriting and [[risk management]], claims management, marketing and sales analysis, [[market penetration]] studies. * [[Mass media|Media]]: [[Target market]] identification, subscriber demographics, [[media planning]]. * [[Real estate]]: Site reports, comprehensive site analysis, retail modeling, presentation quality maps. * [[Retail]]: Site selection, maximize per-store sales, identify under-performing stores, market analysis. * [[Transportation]]: Transport planning, route monitoring. * [[K-12]] : School Site Selection, enrollment planning, school attendance area modification (boundary change), school consolidation, district consolidation, student achievement plotting.
== See also == * [[Geographic information system]] (GIS)
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Business intelligence]] [[Category:Market research]] [[Category:Strategic management]] [[Category:Geographic data and information]]

revision.comment: remove disambiguation info from text
revision.text:
[[Image:MSquares.gif|right|200px|thumb|A Marsden Square map]] '''Marsden square''' mapping or '''Marsden squares''' is a system that divides a chart of the world with latitude-longitude gridlines (e.g. [[plate carrée projection]], [[Mercator Projection|Mercator]] or other) between [[80th parallel north|80°N]] and [[70th parallel south|70°S]] latitudes (or [[north pole|90°N]] and [[80th parallel south|80°S]]: refer chart at Ocean Teacher’s [http://ioc.unesco.org/oceanteacher/OceanTeacher2/06_OcDtaMgtProc/01_DataOps/06_OcDtaForm/01_OcDtaFormFunda/02_Geography/03_SquaresSheets/OceanSquaresMapsheets.htm Ocean Geography] page) into grid cells of 10° [[latitude]] by 10° [[longitude]], each with a unique, numeric identifier. [[William Marsden (orientalist)|William Marsden]], when first secretary of the Admiralty, conceived of this method for collecting and combining information respecting the oceans <ref> [https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Weather_Book.html?id=qNK7AAAAIAAJ Robert Fitzroy, "The Weather Book: A Manual of Practical Meteorology," Longman, Green, Longman, Roberts, & Green (1863), p.49.]</ref>.
== Structure & Design == On the plate carrée projection the grid cells appear square, however if the Mercator projection is used, the grid cells appear “stretched” vertically nearer the tops and bottoms of the map.
On the actual surface of the [[Globe]], the cells are approximately “square” only adjacent to the equator, and become progressively narrower and tapered (also with curved northern and southern boundaries) as they approach the poles, and cells adjoining the poles are unique in possessing three faces rather than four.
Each one of the 540 10°x10° squares is allocated a number from 1 to 288 and from 300 to 551 (see image to the right), plus the sequence extends to 936 in higher latitudes, and then can also be subdivided into 100 one-degree squares numbered from 00 to 99 in order to improve accuracy.
== Use == Marsden squares have mostly been used for identifying the geographic position of [[Meteorology|meteorological]] data, and are described further in various publications of the [[World Meteorological Organization]] (WMO). The 10°x10° square identifiers typically use a minimal number of characters (between 1 and 3 digits) which was/is an operational advantage for low bandwidth transmission systems.
However the rules for allocating numbers to squares do not follow a consistent pattern, so that reverse-engineering (decoding) the relevant square boundaries from any particular Marsden Square identifier is not particularly straightforward (a look-up table is probably the simplest in practice).
Slightly confusingly, an alternative (and more consistent), four-digit notation for global 10°x10° squares is actually known as [[World Meteorological Organization squares]] but does not seem to be actively promoted by the WMO itself.
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
{{-}} {{Geocoding-systems}}
[[Category:Geocodes]]

revision.text:
The '''Most Ancient European Towns Network''' is a [[working group]] of the oldest [[cities in Europe]]. It was founded in 1994, with the idea coming from the town of [[Argos]] in Greece, presented to the [[European Union]]. The group exists to discuss issues such as archaeological research, tourism and incorporating monuments into urban planning.
==Members== The members include the following cities. The chairmanship of the group rotates between the members.<ref name="Members">{{cite web|url=http://www.argos.gr/diktyoe.htm |title=diktyo |first= |last=MAETN |work=classic-web.archive.org |year=1999 |accessdate=19 May 2011 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051022022345/http://www.argos.gr/diktyoe.htm |archivedate=October 22, 2005 }}</ref><ref name="Worms city council website">{{cite web |url= http://www.worms.de/de/kultur/stadtgeschichte/aelteste-stadt-deutschlands.php |title=worms.de > Kultur > älteste deutsche Stadt |first= |last=Worms city council|work=worms.de |year=2011 |accessdate=19 May 2011}}</ref>
*{{flagicon|GRE}} [[Argos]] (Greece)<ref name="Members"/> *{{flagicon|FRA}} [[Béziers]] (France)<ref name="Members"/> *{{flagicon|ESP}} [[Cádiz]] (Spain)<ref name="Members"/> *{{flagicon|GBR}} [[Colchester]] (United Kingdom)<ref name="Members"/> *{{flagicon|IRL}} [[Cork (city)|Cork]] (Ireland)<ref name="Members"/> *{{flagicon|POR}} [[Évora]] (Portugal)<ref name="Members"/> *{{flagicon|NED}} [[Maastricht]] (Netherlands)<ref name="Members"/> *{{flagicon|DEN}} [[Roskilde]] (Denmark)<ref name="Members"/> *{{flagicon|BEL}} [[Tongeren]] (Belgium)<ref name="Members"/> *{{flagicon|GER}} [[Worms, Germany|Worms]] (Germany)<ref name="Members"/><ref name="Worms city council website"/>
The first meeting was held on 22–26 June 1994.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.worms.de/de/kultur/stadtgeschichte/aelteste-stadt-deutschlands.php Worms website] {{de icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081122033820/http://www.coe.int/t/e/legal_affairs/local_and_regional_democracy/documentation/library/transfrontier_cooperation/tfc_cultural_heritage.pdf Council of Europe] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051022022345/http://www.argos.gr/diktyoe.htm Archive of the MAETN's website]
{{Most Ancient European Towns Network}}
