title = The Fatal Journey: The Final Expedition of Henry Hudson | publisher = Basic Books | year = 2009 | location = | pages = }}</ref> *1611 – Mangazeyan men reach the [[Khatanga River|Khatanga]].<ref name=Armstrong2010>{{cite book | last = Armstrong | first = Terence | title = Russian Settlement in the North | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 2010 | isbn = | url = | page = }}</ref> *1612–13 – [[Thomas Button]] is the first to explore the western shores of [[Hudson Bay]], where he winters in the mouth of the [[Nelson River]]; also discovers [[Coats Island|Coats]] and [[Southampton Island]]s.<ref name=Christy/> *1614 – [[History of whaling|Whalers]] discover [[Jan Mayen]].<ref name=Hacq>Hacquebord, Louwrens (2004). "The Jan Mayen Whaling Industry" in ''Jan Mayen Island in Scientific Focus'', Stig Skreslet, editor, Springer Verlag.</ref> *1615–16 – Étienne Brûlé sights the western shore of [[Lake Ontario]], descends the [[Niagara River]], explores what are now parts of modern [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[Pennsylvania]], and descends the [[Susquehanna River]] to [[Chesapeake Bay]].<ref name=Butterfield/> *1616 – [[Jacob Le Maire]] and [[Willem Schouten]] discover and name [[Le Maire Strait]], [[Isla de los Estados|Staten Island]], and [[Cape Horn]]; also discover [[Tonga]] ([[Niuafo'ou]], [[Niuatoputapu]], and [[Tafahi]]), [[Futuna Island, Wallis and Futuna|Futuna]] and [[Alofi]] (in modern [[Wallis and Futuna]]), and several islands in the [[Tuamotu Archipelago|Tuamotu]] ([[Takaroa]], [[Takapoto]], [[Manihi]], [[Ahe]] and [[Rangiroa]]) and [[Bismarck Archipelago]]s (including [[New Hanover Island|New Hanover]] and [[New Ireland (island)|New Ireland]]).<ref name=Morison1974/><ref name=Quanchi/> *1616 – [[Robert Bylot]] and [[William Baffin]] reach 77°30′ N, enter [[Baffin Bay]], discover [[Smith Sound|Smith]], [[Jones Sound|Jones]], and [[Lancaster Sound]]s and sight the coasts of [[Ellesmere Island|Ellesmere]], [[Devon Island|Devon]], and [[Bylot Island]]s.<ref name=Markham>{{cite book | last = Markham | first = Clements | title = The voyages of William Baffin, 1612–1622 | publisher = Hakluyt Society | year = 1881 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=pmcMAAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=William+Baffin&hl=en&ei=iGxUTJDPKZKcsQOzy_3ZAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1616 – [[Dirk Hartog]] explores some {{convert|576|km|mi}} of coastline (the coast of [[Western Australia]] from about 22° to 28° S), discovering [[Dirk Hartog Island]] and [[Shark Bay]].<ref name=Wood>{{cite book | last = Wood | first = George Arnold | title = The discovery of Australia | publisher = Macmillan & Company | year = 1922 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=lHnOAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1617 – [[England|English]] [[walrus]] hunters sight the southern coast of "Sir Thomas Smith's Island" ([[Nordaustlandet]]).<ref name=Conway/> *1618 – [[Pedro Páez]] is believed to be the first European to see and describe the source of the [[Blue Nile]] in Ethiopia.<ref name=Budge>{{cite book | last = Budge | first = E.A. Wallis | authorlink = E. A. Wallis Budge | title = A History of Ethiopia: Nubia and Abyssinia, 1928 | publisher = Oosterhout: Anthropological Publications | year = 1970 | location = | url = }}</ref> *1618 – [[Lenaert Jacobszoon]] discovers an "island" at 22° S (the coast of Western Australia from [[Point Cloates]] to [[North West Cape]]).<ref name=Mutch/> *1619 – [[Frederick de Houtman]] sights the coast of Western Australia near [[Fremantle, Western Australia|Fremantle]] and sails along the coast north for over {{convert|640|km|mi}}.<ref name=Mutch/> *1620 – Mangazeyan serving men reach the [[Vilyuy River]] and descend it to its confluence with the [[Lena River|Lena]].<ref name=Fisher1943/> *1621–23 – Étienne Brûlé and his companion Grenolle travel along the [[North Channel (Ontario)|North Channel]] of Lake Huron (probably sighting [[Manitoulin Island]]) to "Grand Lac" ([[Lake Superior]]) via [[St. Marys River (Michigan–Ontario)|St. Mary's River]].<ref name=Butterfield/> *1622 – The [[Netherlands|Dutch]] ship ''Leeuwin'' discovers land near present-day [[Cape Leeuwin]].<ref name=Wood/> *1623 – [[Jan Carstenszoon]] discovers the western coast of Cape York Peninsula from Cape Keerweer to the southern mouth of the [[Gilbert-Einasleigh River|Gilbert River]]; while his consort '''Willem Joosten van Colster''' discovers "Arnhemsland" and "Speultsland" (modern [[Arnhem Land]] and perhaps [[Groote Eylandt]]).<ref name=Wood/><ref name=Peters>{{cite book | last = Peters | first = Nonja | title = The Dutch down under, 1606–2006. | publisher = University of Western Australia Press | year = 2006 | location = Crawley, W.A.}}</ref> *1624 – [[António de Andrade]] crosses the [[Himalayas]] through the [[Mana Pass]] and reaches [[Tibet]].<ref name=Wessels/> *1627 – [[Jesuit]] missionaries [[Estêvão Cacella]] and [[João Cabral]] cross the [[Himalayas]] and are the first to enter [[Bhutan]].<ref name=Wessels/><ref name=Kapadia>{{cite book | last = Kapadia | first = Harish | title = Into the untravelled Himalaya: travels, treks, and climbs | publisher = Indus Publishing | year = 2005 | isbn = 81-7387-181-7 | page = 72}}</ref> *1627 – [[François Thijssen]], accompanied by [[Pieter Nuyts]], discovers over {{convert|1609|km|mi}} of coastline east of [[Cape Leeuwin]] to the eastern end of the [[Great Australian Bight]].<ref name=Mutch/> *1628 – Cabral is the first to enter [[Nepal]].<ref name=Wessels/> *1628 – Gerrit Frederikszoon de Witt captain of the [[Vianen (ship)|''Vianen'']] discovers "Witsland" about 21° S, sailing {{convert|320|km|mi}} along the coast and discovering [[Barrow Island (Western Australia)|Barrow Island]] and parts of the [[Dampier Archipelago]].<ref name=Wood/> *1628–30 – Vasilii Bugor ascends the [[Upper Tunguska]] and portages to the upper Lena, descending it to its confluence with the [[Kirenga River|Kirenga]].<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=Fisher1943/> *1631–32 – [[Luke Foxe]] and [[Thomas James (sea captain)|Thomas James]], in separate expeditions, both circumnavigate Hudson Bay in search of a Northwest Passage; Foxe sails through [[Foxe Channel|the channel]] and into [[Foxe Basin|the basin]] now named after him to 66°47′ N, while James winters in the bay [[James Bay|named after him]].<ref name=Christy>{{cite book | last = Christy | first = Miller | title = The voyages of Captain Luke Foxe of Hull, and Captain Thomas James of Bristol, in search of a northwest passage, in 1631–32; with narratives of the earlier northwest voyages of Frobisher, Davis, Weymouth, Hall, Knight, Hudson, Button, Gibbons, Bylot, Baffin, Hawkridge, and others | publisher = Hakluyt Society | year = 1894 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Vh87AAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=related:STANFORD36105004846502#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1632–33 – [[Pyotr Beketov]] descends the Lena as far as its great bend, erects the ostrog [[Yakutsk]], and sends a detachment some {{convert|720|km|mi}} downriver (where the ''zimovie'' [[Zhigansky District|Zhigansk]] is built) and another east up the [[Aldan River|Aldan]] as far as the [[Amga River|Amga]] (which they also ascend in search of [[yasak]]).<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=Forsyth/> *1633–34 – [[Jean Nicolet]] discovers [[Lake Michigan]] and likely reaches [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]].<ref name=Fischer>{{cite book | last = Fischer | first = David Hackett | title = Champlain's Dream: The European Founding of North America. | publisher = Simon & Schuster | year = 2008 | location = New York}}</ref> *1633–38 – [[Ilya Perfilyev]] and Ivan Rebrov sail from Zhigansk in kochi some {{convert|800|km|mi}} downriver to the mouth of the Lena and sail along the coast east and west, reaching the mouths of the [[Olenyok River|Olenyok]], [[Yana River|Yana]], and [[Indigirka River|Indigirka]] rivers.<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=March>{{cite book | last = March | first = G. Patrick | title = Eastern destiny: Russia in Asia and the North Pacific | publisher = Praeger | year = 1996 | location = Westport, Conn | page = }}</ref> *1638–40 – Poznik Ivanov crosses the [[Verkhoyansk Range]] into the upper reaches of the Yana, and then portages over the [[Chersky Range]] into the Indigirka River system.<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=March/> *1639–40 – [[Maksim Perfilyev]] ascends the [[Vitim River]] to the [[Tsipa River|Tsipa]], which he also ascends (until rapids force him to turn back), becoming the first Russian to enter [[Transbaikal]].<ref name=Lantzeff/> *1639–41 – [[Ivan Moskvitin]] ascends the [[Maya River|Maya]], portages across the [[Dzhugdzhur Mountains]], and descends the [[Ulya River|Ulya]] to the [[Sea of Okhotsk]]; two groups are sent to the north and south, reaching the mouths of the [[Taui Bay|Taui]] and [[Uda River (Khabarovsk Krai)|Uda]] rivers, respectively.<ref name=Lincoln/><ref name=Lantzeff/> *1641 – Dmitri Zyrian discovers the [[Alazeya River|Alazeya]], which he ascends as far as the [[tree line]].<ref name=Lantzeff/> *1642–43 – [[Abel Tasman]] discovers "Anthony van Diemenslandt" ([[Tasmania]]) and "Staten Landt" ([[New Zealand]]); following year discovers "'t Eylandt Amsterdam" ([[Tongatapu]]), [[Fiji]] and [[New Britain]].<ref name=Quanchi/><ref name=Wood/> *1643 – [[Kurbat Ivanov]] reaches the western shores of [[Lake Baikal]], opposite [[Olkhon]].<ref name=Haywood>{{cite book | last = Haywood | first = A. J. | title = Siberia: a cultural history | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 2010 | location = Oxford | page = }}</ref> *1643 – [[Maarten Gerritsz Vries]] sails along the eastern coast of "Yezo" ([[Hokkaidō]]), between [[Iturup]] and [[Urup]], to [[Sakhalin]].<ref name=Whitfield/> *1643 – Vasiliy Sychev discovers the [[Anabar River|Anabar]], where he establishes the ''zimovie'' Anabarskoye.<ref name=Armstrong2010/><ref name=Holland>{{cite book | last = Holland | first = Clive | title = Arctic Exploration and Development, c. 500 B.C. to 1915: an encyclopedia | publisher = Garland | year = 1994 | location = New York | url = | page = }}</ref> *1643–45 – [[Vassili Poyarkov]] crosses the [[Stanovoy Range]] and descends the [[Zeya River|Zeya]] to the [[Amur River|Amur]], which he follows to its mouth; from here, he coasts along the Sea of Okhotsk to the Ulya (on the way sighting the [[Shantar Islands]]).<ref name=Golder>{{cite book | last = Golder | first = Frank Alfred | title = Russian expansion on the Pacific, 1641–1850 an account of the earliest and later expeditions made by the Russians along the Pacific coast of Asia and North America; including some related expeditions to the Arctic regions | publisher = Authur H. Clark Co. | year = 1914 | location = Cleveland | page = }}</ref> *1644 – Tasman maps the northern coast of Australia, connecting "Nova Guinea" (the Cape York Peninsula) with "the land of D'Eendracht" (Western Australia).<ref name=Wood/> *1644 – [[Mikhail Stadukhin]] reaches the [[Kolyma River|Kolyma]].<ref name=Lantzeff/> *1644–47 – Ivan Pokhabov is the first to ascend the Angara to Lake Baikal, which he crosses to the [[Selenga River|Selenga]]; he later ascends it and reaches [[Ulaanbaatar|Urga]] (in present-day [[Mongolia]]).<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=Forsyth/> *1646 – Isaya Ignatyev reaches [[Chaunskaya Bay]].<ref name=Vaughan>{{cite book | last = Vaughan | first = Richard | title = The Arctic: A History | publisher = A. Sutton | year = 2007 | location = Stroud | page = }}</ref> *1648–49 – [[Semyon Dezhnyov]] sails from the Kolyma, rounds [[Cape Dezhnev]] (thus proving Asia and America are separate), and reaches the [[Anadyr River]], which he ascends for some {{convert|563|km|mi}} (here he builds the ''zimovie'' [[Anadyrsk]]).<ref name=Lincoln/> *1649–51 – [[Yerofey Khabarov]] ascends the [[Olyokma River]], crosses the northern [[Yablonoi Mountains]], and descends the Amur to its confluence with the [[Songhua River|Songhua]].<ref name=Lincoln/><ref name=Golder/> *1650 – Stadukhin and Semen Motora travel from the Kolyma, across the Anyuyskiy Range, to Anadyrsk.<ref name=Lincoln/> *1651–57 – Stadukhin travels from Anadyrsk to the mouth of the [[Penzhina Bay|Penzhina River]], then west along the northern coast of the Sea of Okhotsk to [[Okhotsk]].<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=March/> *1653–54 – Beketov ascends the [[Khilok River|Khilok]], crosses the southern Yablonoi Mountains, and descends the [[Ingoda River|Ingoda]] and [[Shilka River|Shilka]] rivers to the latter's confluence with the [[Nercha River|Nercha]] (where his men build the ostrog [[Nerchinsk]]).<ref name=Lantzeff/> *1654 – [[Médard Chouart des Groseilliers]] explores the entire western shore of Lake Michigan.<ref name=DeVoto/> *1659 – Groseilliers and [[Pierre-Esprit Radisson]] explore the southern shore of Lake Superior as far west as [[Chequamegon Bay]].<ref name=DeVoto/> *1661 – [[Johann Grueber]] and [[Albert Dorville]] are the first to visit [[Lhasa]].<ref name=Sandberg>{{cite book | last = Sandberg | first = Graham | title = The Exploration of Tibet, its history and particulars from 1623 to 1904 | publisher = Thacker, Spink & Co. | year = 1904 | location = Calcutta | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=OgRxAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA15&dq=European+exploration+Tibet&hl=en&ei=5U-2TM_VMpCssAOLn_TDCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1669 – [[René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle|Robert de la Salle]] discovers the [[Ohio River|Ohio]], descending it as far as the [[Falls of the Ohio National Wildlife Conservation Area|Falls of Ohio]] at the site of modern [[Louisville, Kentucky]].<ref name=Parkman/> *1673 – [[Louis Jolliet]] and [[Jacques Marquette]] reach the upper Mississippi, descending it to its confluence with the [[Arkansas River|Arkansas]]; also discover the [[Missouri River|Missouri]].<ref name=Parkman/> *1675 – [[Anthony de la Roché]] discovers [[South Georgia Island|South Georgia]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} *1682 – Robert de La Salle descends the "Rivière de Colbert" ([[Mississippi River|Mississippi]]) to its mouth.<ref name=Parkman>{{cite book | last = Parkman | first = Francis | title = La Salle and the Discovery of the Great West | publisher = The Modern Library | year = 1999 | location = New York | page = }}</ref> *1688–89 – [[Jacques de Noyon]] discovers [[Rainy Lake]] and [[Lake of the Woods]].<ref name=DeVoto/> *1690–92 – [[Henry Kelsey]] travels from [[York Factory, Manitoba|York Factory]] southwestward, probably reaching the [[Saskatchewan River|Saskatchewan]] and the headwaters of the [[Assiniboine River|Assiniboine]]—in the process becoming the first European to see the [[Canadian Prairies]].<ref name=DeVoto/> *1696 – [[Luka Morozko]] travels almost halfway down the west coast of [[Kamchatka Peninsula|Kamchatka]], reaching the [[Tigil River]].<ref name=March/> *1697–99 – [[Vladimir Atlasov]] reaches as far as the [[Golygina River]] on the southwest coast of Kamchatka, from which he sights [[Atlasov Island]]; also crosses the [[Sredinny Range]] (twice), reaching [[Olyutorsky Gulf]] and the [[Kamchatka River]].<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=March/>
==18th century== [[File:Cook new zealand.jpg|thumb|Cook's map of New Zealand]] [[File:Hodges, Resolution and Adventure in Matavai Bay.jpg|thumb|''[[HMS Resolution (Cook)|Resolution]] and [[HMS Adventure (1771)|Adventure]] in Matavai Bay'' by [[William Hodges]]]] [[File:Vancouver-Rainier.jpg|thumb|"Mount Rainier from the south Part of Admiralty Inlet". The mountain was discovered by Vancouver during his exploration of Puget Sound in the spring of 1792.]] [[File:Alex MacKenzie from Canada by land.jpg|thumb|300px|Inscription at the end of the Alexander Mackenzie's Canada crossing located at {{coord|52|22|43|N|127|28|14|W}}]]
*1706 – Mikhail Nasedkin reaches [[Cape Lopatka]] and sights [[Shumshu]], northernmost of the [[Kuril Islands]].<ref name=March/> *1710 – [[Yakov Permyakov]] discovers [[Bolshoy Lyakhovsky Island]].{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} *1713 – Ivan Kozyrevsky reaches Shumshu and [[Paramushir]].<ref name=March/> *1714 – [[Étienne de Veniard, Sieur de Bourgmont]] ascends the Missouri as far as the [[Platte River|Platte]], becoming the first to enter the present-day [[Nebraska]].<ref name=Hayes/> *1720 – Pedro de Villasur travels from Santa Fe, through what is now part of southeastern [[Colorado]], to the lower Platte in eastern Nebraska.<ref name=Hayes/> *1722 – [[Jakob Roggeveen]] discovers "Paasch Eiland" ([[Easter Island]]) and [[Tutuila]] and [[Upolu]].<ref name=Fischer2005>{{cite book | last = Fischer | first = Steven R. | title = Island at the End of the World: the Turbulent History of Easter Island | publisher = Reaktion | year = 2005 | location = London | url = }}</ref><ref name=Tcherkezoff>{{cite book | last = Tcherkezoff | first = Serge | title = First contacts in Polynesia: the Samoan case (1722–1848) : western misunderstanding about sexuality and divinity | publisher = ANUE Press | year = 2008 | location = Canberra | url = }}</ref> *1728 – [[Vitus Bering]] sails through the strait that now bears his name; also discovers and names [[Saint Lawrence Island]].<ref name=Vaughan/> *1732 – [[Mikhail Gvozdev]] discovers the "Large Country" ([[Alaska]]).<ref name=Golder/> *1734 – [[Jean Baptiste de La Vérendrye]] discovers [[Lake Winnipeg]].<ref name=DeVoto>{{cite book | last = DeVoto | first = Bernard | title = The Course of Empire | publisher = Houghton Mifflin | year = 1980 | location = Boston | page = }}</ref> *1734–37 – Stepan Muravev and Mikhail Pavlov chart the Russian coast from [[Arkhangelsk]] to just east of the [[Pechora River|Pechora]], while [[Stepan Malygin]] charts it from there to the Ob River, including the [[Yamal Peninsula]].<ref name=Lincoln/> *1735–36 – [[Vasili Pronchishchev]] charts the Russian coast from the Lena west to the [[Khatanga River|Khatanga]].<ref name=Lincoln/> *1737 – [[Dmitry Ovtsyn]] charts the Russian coast from the mouth of the Ob to the Yenisei.<ref name=Lincoln/> *1738 – [[Pierre Gaultier de Varennes, sieur de La Vérendrye|Pierre de La Vérendrye]] visits [[Mandan]] villages near the site of present-day [[Bismarck, North Dakota]].<ref name=Parkman1893>{{cite book | last = Parkman | first = Francis | title = France and England in North America: A Series of Historical Narratives | publisher = Little, Brown | year = 1893 | location = Boston | url = }}</ref> *1738–40 – [[Fyodor Minin]] charts the Russian coast from the Yenisei to the Pyasina.<ref name=Lincoln/> *1739 – [[Jean-Baptiste Charles Bouvet de Lozier|Jean Bouvet de Lozier]] discovers "Cape Circumcision" ([[Bouvet Island]]).<ref name=Mills/> *1739–41 – [[Dmitry Laptev]] charts the Russian coast from the Lena to just east of the Kolyma.<ref name=Lincoln/> *1741 – Bering sights [[Mount Saint Elias|Mount St. Elias]], the entrance of [[Prince William Sound]], the [[Alaska Peninsula]] (from Cape Providence to Chignik Bay) and several of the [[Aleutian Islands]] (discovering [[Great Sitkin Island|Great Sitkin]], [[Atka Island|Atka]], and [[Kiska]]), as well as discovering [[Kayak Island|Kayak]], [[Montague Island (Alaska)|Montague]], [[Hinchinbrook Island (Alaska)|Hinchinbrook]], [[Sitkalidak Island|Sitkalidak]], and the [[Shumagin Islands|Shumagin]] and [[Commander Islands]]; his second-in-command, [[Aleksei Chirikov]], sights [[Mount Fairweather|Mounts Fairweather]] and [[Mount Douglas (Alaska)|Douglas]] and discovers Noyes and [[Baker Island (Alaska)|Baker Island]]s (both off the west coast of [[Prince of Wales Island (Alaska)|Prince of Wales Island]]), as well as [[Baranof Island|Baranof]], [[Chichagof Island|Chichagof]], [[Kruzof Island|Kruzof]], [[Yakobi Island|Yakobi]], [[Kodiak Island|Kodiak]], [[Afognak]], the Aleutian Islands ([[Umnak]], [[Adak Island|Adak]], [[Agattu]], [[Attu Island|Attu]], and the [[Islands of Four Mountains]]), and the [[Kenai Peninsula]].<ref name=Golder1922>{{cite book | last = Golder | first = Frank Alfred and Leonhard Stejneger | title = Bering’s voyages: an account of the efforts of the Russians to determine the relation of Asia and America | publisher = American Geographical Society | year = 1922 | location = New York | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=7P0HAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA36-IA2&dq=bering+1741+voyage&hl=en&ei=cG0BTYGNIIinnAfDv-HlDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1741–42 – [[Khariton Laptev]] and [[Semion Chelyuskin]] chart the [[Taymyr Peninsula]], with the latter reaching [[Cape Chelyuskin]], the northernmost point of Asia.<ref name=Lincoln/> *1742 – [[Christopher Middleton (navigator)|Christopher Middleton]] discovers [[Wager Bay]] and [[Repulse Bay, Nunavut|Repulse Bay]].<ref name=Williams2003>{{cite book | last = Williams | first = Glyndwr | title = Voyages of delusion: the quest for the Northwest Passage | publisher = Yale University Press | year = 2003 | location = New Haven | page = }}</ref> *1742–43 – [[Louis-Joseph Gaultier de La Vérendrye]] and his brother [[François de La Vérendrye|François]] reach the [[Big Horn Mountains]] of modern [[Wyoming]]; on their return they reach the vicinity of present-day [[Pierre, South Dakota]].<ref name=Parkman1893/><ref>Champagne, Father Antoine. The Vérendryes and Their Succossors, 1727–1760 (MHS Transactions, Series 3, No. 25, 1968–69 Season).</ref> *1747 – Jeremiah Westall discovers [[Chesterfield Inlet]] and sails about sixty miles up it.<ref name=Williams2003/> *1761–62 – William Christopher sails {{convert|370|km|mi}} into Chesterfield Inlet to the western end of [[Baker Lake, Nunavut|Baker Lake]].<ref name=Williams2003/> *1767 – [[Samuel Wallis]] discovers "King George's Land" ([[Tahiti]]).<ref name=Hough>{{cite book | last = Hough | first = Richard | title = Captain James Cook: a biography | publisher = Norton | year = 1994 | location = New York | page = }}</ref> *1769 – José Ortega discovers [[San Francisco Bay]].<ref name=Hayes2007/> *1769–70 – [[James Cook]] circumnavigates both islands of New Zealand, proving they aren't part of [[Terra Australis Incognita]]; also discovers the east coast of Australia from [[Cape Howe]] to [[Cape York Peninsula|Cape York]].<ref name=Hough/> *1771–72 – [[Samuel Hearne]] reaches the [[Coppermine River|Coppermine]], descending it to what would become known as [[Coronation Gulf]]; the following year, on his way back, he becomes the first to sight and cross [[Great Slave Lake]].<ref name=Hayes/> *1772 – [[Yves-Joseph de Kerguelen-Trémarec]] discovers the [[Kerguelen Islands]].<ref name=Mills/> *1772 – [[Pedro Fages]] sights the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Farquhar |first=Francis P. |title=History of the Sierra Nevada |publisher=University of California Press |year=2007 |page= |isbn=0-520-25395-7}}</ref> *1773 – [[Ivan Lyakhov]] reaches [[Kotelny Island]].<ref name=Vaughan/> *1773–75 – Cook is the first to cross the [[Antarctic Circle]], reaching 71° 10’ S, thus finally disproving the existence of Terra Australis Incognita; also discovers [[New Caledonia]] and the [[South Sandwich Islands]].<ref name=Hough/> *1774 – [[Juan José Pérez Hernández]] explores the western coast of [[North America]] from [[Cape Mendocino]] northwards, discovering the [[Queen Charlotte Islands]], [[Vancouver Island]], and [[Dall Island]].<ref name=Hayes2001>{{cite book | last = Hayes | first = Derek | title = Historical atlas of the North Pacific Ocean: maps of discovery and scientific exploration, 1500–2000 | publisher = Douglas & McIntyre | year = 2001 | location = Vancouver | url = }}</ref> *1775 – [[Bruno de Heceta]] discovers the mouth of the [[Columbia River]]; his consort [[Juan Francisco de la Bodega y Quadra]] discovers [[Prince of Wales Island (Alaska)|Prince of Wales Island]] ([[Bucareli Bay]]).<ref name=Hayes1999>{{cite book | last = Hayes | first = Derek | title = Historical atlas of the Pacific Northwest: Maps of exploration and discovery; British Columbia, Washington, Oregon, Alaska, Yukon | publisher = Sasquatch Books | year = 1999 | location = Seattle | url = }}</ref> *1776 – [[Francisco Atanasio Domínguez]] and [[Silvestre Vélez de Escalante]] follow the Rio Grande north to the modern state of [[Colorado]], where they travel west, discovering [[Utah Lake]].<ref name=Hayes/> *1777–78 – Cook discovers [[Kiritimati|Christmas Island]] and [[Hawaii]]; also explores the Alaskan coast as far north as [[Icy Cape, Alaska|Icy Cape]], discovering [[Cook Inlet]] and [[Prince William Sound]].<ref name=Hough/> *1787 – [[Charles William Barkley]] discovers the [[Strait of Juan de Fuca]].<ref name=Williams2003/> *1788 – [[Captain Arthur Phillip]] arrives with [[The First Fleet]] in [[Botany Bay]] on the coast of [[Sydney, Australia]]. *1789 – [[Alexander Mackenzie (explorer)|Alexander Mackenzie]] descends the [[Mackenzie River]] to its mouth in the [[Arctic Ocean]].<ref name=Mackenzie1801>{{cite book | last = Mackenzie | first = Alexander | title = Voyages from Montreal, on the river St. Lawrence, through the continent of North America, to the Frozen and Pacific oceans; in the years 1789 and 1793 | publisher = T. Cadell, jun. and W. Davies | year = 1801 | location = London | url = }}</ref> *1791 – [[Francisco de Eliza]] discovers the "Canal de Nuestra Señora del Rosario" ([[Strait of Georgia]]); [[José María Narváez]] explores up it, passing the mouth of the [[Fraser River]] and reaching as far north as [[Texada Island]].<ref name=Hayes1999/> *1791–94 – [[George Vancouver]], together with [[William Robert Broughton|William Broughton]], [[Peter Puget]], [[Joseph Whidbey]], and [[James Johnstone (explorer)|James Johnstone]], charts the modern states of [[Oregon]] and [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]], the coast of [[British Columbia]], and the [[Alaska Panhandle]], discovering [[Admiralty Island|Admiralty]], [[Mitkof Island|Mitkof]] and [[Wrangell Island]]s in the [[Alexander Archipelago]], as well as proving the insularity of [[Kuiu Island|Kuiu]] and [[Revillagigedo Island]]s; also charts [[Admiralty Inlet]] and [[Puget Sound]] and discovers the [[Chatham Islands]] and [[Snares Islands / Tini Heke|The Snares]].<ref name=Vancouver>{{cite book | last = Vancouver | first = George, and John Vancouver | title = A voyage of discovery to the North Pacific ocean, and round the world | publisher = J. Stockdale | year = 1801; vols. I-VI | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=qwol8bPaYxsC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1792 – [[Dionisio Alcalá Galiano]] and [[Cayetano Valdés y Flores]] circumnavigate Vancouver Island, proving its insularity.<ref name=Hayes/> *1792 – [[Jacinto Caamaño]] enters [[Clarence Strait]], showing that much of the Alaska Panhandle is an archipelago, not mainland, as had been presumed; also sights the southwest coast of Revillagigedo Island.<ref name=Hayes/> *1792–93 – Mackenzie ascends the [[Peace River (Canada)|Peace]] and [[Parsnip River|Parsnip]], crosses the [[Canadian Rockies]] to the headwaters of the [[Fraser River|Fraser]], ascends the [[West Road River]] and crosses the [[Coast Mountains]], reaching the [[Bella Coola River|Bella Coola]], which he descends to [[North Bentinck Arm]] and [[Dean Channel]].<ref name=Mackenzie1801/> *1796 – [[Mungo Park (explorer)|Mungo Park]] reaches the upper [[Niger River|Niger]], exploring it from [[Ségou]] to [[Silla, Mali|Silla]].<ref name=Fernandez-Armesto>{{cite book | last = Fernandez-Armesto | first = Felipe | title = Pathfinders: A Global History of Exploration | publisher = W.W. Norton & Company | year = 2006 | location = New York | url = }}</ref> *1797–98 – [[George Bass]] explores from Cape Howe to [[Western Port]], discovering [[Bass Strait]].<ref name=Wood/> *1798 – [[John Fearn (whaler)|John Fearn]] discovers "Pleasant Island" ([[Nauru]]).<ref name=Quanchi/> *1798 – [[Francisco de Lacerda]] travels from [[Tete, Mozambique|Tete]] northwest to [[Lake Mweru]].<ref name=Jeal1973>{{cite book|last=Jeal|first =Tim|title=Livingstone|publisher = G. P. Putnam’s Sons|year=1973|location=New York|url=}}</ref> *1798–99 – [[Matthew Flinders]] and George Bass circumnavigate Tasmania, proving its insularity.<ref name=Wood/>
==19th century== [[File:Map of Lewis and Clark's Track, Across the Western Portion of North America, published 1814.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The famous map of Lewis and Clark's expedition. It changed mapping of northwest America by providing the first accurate depiction of the relationship of the sources of the [[Columbia River|Columbia]] and [[Missouri River|Missouri]] rivers, and the Rocky Mountains.]] [[File:Descent of Fraser River 1808.jpg|thumb|Colour drawing of Simon Fraser's 1808 descent of the Fraser River.]] [[File:The Crews of H.M.S. Hecla & Griper Cutting Into Winter Harbour, Sept. 26th, 1819.jpg|thumb|"The Crews of H.M.S. Hecla & Griper Cutting Into Winter Harbour, Sept. 26th, 1819". An engraving from the journal published in 1821.]] [[File:Point Turnagain.jpg|thumb|John Franklin's party encamped at Point Turnagain, the furthest point he reached.]] [[File:Nlc hms investigator.jpg|thumb|HMS ''Investigator'', on the northwestern coast of Banks Island, 20 August 1851.]] [[File:McClure Map.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Map drawn by Robert McClure detailing the Northwest Passage, including the 1851 route of the ''Investigator''.]] [[File:Matterhorn ascent Dore.jpg|thumb|upright|The first ascent of the Matterhorn, by [[Gustave Doré]].]] [[File:Fly River Map 1876 NLA.jpg|thumb|250px|right|The original survey map created by L.M. D'Albertis in 1876.]] [[File:Nansen Johansen depart 14 March 1895.jpg|thumb|alt= A group of men pose on the ice with dogs and sledges, with the ship's outline visible in the background|Nansen and Johansen finally depart on their polar journey, 14 March 1895. Nansen is the tall figure, second from left; Johansen is standing second from right.]]
*1800 – [[James Grant (navigator)|James Grant]] discovers the Australian coastline from [[Cape Banks]] to [[Cape Otway]].<ref name=Wood/> *c. 1801–04 – A fur trading post is built on [[Great Bear Lake]].<ref name=Keith>{{cite book | last = Keith | first = Lloyd | title = North of Athabasca: Slave Lake and Mackenzie River documents of the North West Company, 1800–1821 | publisher = McGill-Queen's University Press | year = 2001 | location = Rupert's Land Record Society series. Montreal | url = }}</ref> *1802 – [[John Murray (Australian explorer)|John Murray]] discovers [[Port Phillip Bay]].<ref name=Wood/> *1802 – Matthew Flinders explores the coast from [[Fowlers Bay, South Australia|Fowlers Bay]] to [[Encounter Bay]], discovering [[Spencer Gulf]], [[Kangaroo Island]], and [[Gulf St Vincent|Gulf St. Vincent]].<ref name=Wood/> *1802 – [[Nicolas Baudin]] explores the coast from Cape Banks to Encounter Bay, where he meets Flinders.<ref name=Wood/> *1802–03 – Flinders circumnavigates Australia.<ref name=Wood/> *1805–06 – [[Meriwether Lewis]] and [[William Clark (explorer)|William Clark]], from [[Fort Mandan]], ascend the Missouri to its headwaters, cross the [[Continental Divide of the Americas|Continental Divide]] via [[Lemhi Pass]] in the [[Bitterroot Range]] to enter the present state of [[Idaho]], and descend the [[Clearwater River (Idaho)|Clearwater]] and [[Snake River|Snake river]]s to the Columbia, which they descend to its mouth; on the way back Lewis explores the [[Blackfoot River (Montana)|Blackfoot]] and [[Sun River|Sun river]]s, as well as the headwaters of the [[Marias River|Marias]], while Clark travels through [[Bozeman Pass]] and descends the [[Yellowstone River|Yellowstone]] to its confluence with the Missouri.<ref name=Ambrose>{{cite book | last = Ambrose | first = Stephen E. | title = Undaunted Courage: Meriwether Lewis, Thomas Jefferson, and the Opening of the American West | publisher = Simon & Schuster | year = 1996 | location = New York | url = }}</ref> *1805–06 – Mungo Park descends the Niger as far as the Bussa rapids, where he is drowned.<ref name=Fernandez-Armesto/> *1806 – [[Yakov Sannikov]] discovers [[New Siberia|New Siberia Island]].<ref name=Mills/> *1806 – [[Abraham Bristow]] discovers the [[Auckland Islands]].<ref name=Mawar/> *1808 – [[Simon Fraser (explorer)|Simon Fraser]] descends the [[Fraser River]] for some {{convert|800|km|mi}} to its mouth, reaching the Strait of Georgia.<ref name=Hayes/> *1810 – [[Frederick Hasselborough]] discovers [[Campbell Island, New Zealand|Campbell]] and [[Macquarie Island]]s.<ref name=Mills/> *1811–12 – [[W. Price Hunt|Wilson Price Hunt]] discovers [[Union Pass]] in the [[Wind River Range]] and reaches the upper Snake River, while [[Robert Stuart (explorer)|Robert Stuart]] discovers [[South Pass (Wyoming)|South Pass]]—his route would later become the [[Oregon Trail]].<ref name=Hayes/> *1816 – [[Otto von Kotzebue]] discovers [[Kotzebue Sound]].<ref name=Hayes/> *1819 – [[William Smith (mariner)|William Smith]] discovers the [[South Shetland Islands]].<ref name=Riffenburgh>{{cite book | last = Riffenburgh | first = Beau | title = Encyclopedia of the Antarctic | publisher = CRC Press | year = 2007 | location = New York | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=fRJtB2MNdJMC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=South%20Shetland%20Islands%2C%20Discovery%20of&f=false}}</ref> *1819–20 – [[William Edward Parry]] enters [[Lancaster Sound]] and reaches [[Melville Island (Northwest Territories and Nunavut)|Melville Island]], discovering and naming [[Cornwallis Island (Nunavut)|Cornwallis]], [[Bathurst Island (Canada)|Bathurst]], and [[Somerset Island (Nunavut)|Somerset Island]]s; the following year sights "Banks Land" ([[Banks Island]]).<ref name=Parry>{{cite book | last = Parry | first = William Edward | title = Journal of a voyage for the discovery of a North-West passage from the Atlantic to the Pacific: performed in the years 1819–20 | publisher = John Murray | year = 1821 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=sdM0AAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=William+Edward+Parry+1819&hl=en&ei=bZ5LTM64M46WsgOW2I1J&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1820 – [[Edward Bransfield]] sights the [[Antarctic Peninsula]]; also discovers northernmost islands of the South Shetlands.<ref name=Mills>{{cite book | last = Mills | first = William James | title = Exploring polar frontiers: a historical encyclopedia | publisher = ABC-CLIO | year = 2003 | location = Santa Barbara | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=PYdBH4dOOM4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=Exploring+polar+frontiers&hl=en&ei=I21UTKSmJYWcsQOa2YDbAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1820–21 – [[Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen]] discovers the northernmost islands of the South Sandwich group; following year discovers [[Peter I Island|Peter I]] and [[Alexander Island]]s.<ref>Cook, F. A. ''Captain Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen, 1819–21. The Discovery of Alexander I., Peter I., and other islands'' (Bulletin of the American Geographical Society of New York, Vol. XXXIII, 1901, pp. 36–41).</ref> *1821 – [[John Franklin]] explores over {{convert|800|km|mi}} of coastline from the mouth of the Coppermine River to Point Turnagain on the [[Kent Peninsula]].<ref name=Franklin>{{cite book | last = Franklin | first = John | title = Narrative of a journey to the shores of the Polar Sea, in the years 1819-20-21-22 | publisher = John Murray | year = 1824 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=bN8BAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=John+Franklin&hl=en&ei=pV9QTOSCMoemsQOFr-DYBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1821 – Sealers [[Nathaniel Palmer]] and George Powell discover "Powell's Islands" ([[South Orkney Islands]]).<ref name=Spears>{{cite book | last = Spears | first = John Randolph | title = Captain Nathaniel Brown Palmer, an old-time sailor of the sea. | publisher = The Macmillan company | year = 1922 | location = New York | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=LPwlAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Captain+Nathaniel+Brown+Palmer&hl=en&ei=GgVXTOKvGYbGsAPi7bjaAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1821–23 – Parry explores the eastern side of the [[Melville Peninsula]], reaching the western entrance of [[Fury and Hecla Strait]]; also explores the northern coast of [[Foxe Basin]].<ref name=Parry1824>{{cite book | last = Parry | first = William Edward | title = Journal of a second voyage for the discovery of a north-west passage from the Atlantic to the Pacific: performed in the years 1821-22-23, in His Majesty's ships Fury and Hecla. | publisher = John Murray | year = 1824 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=x4K_clZG0c4C&pg=PP11&dq=William+Edward+Parry+1824&hl=en&ei=kthVTIbGC43ksQPUtd3ZAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1823 – [[Dixon Denham]], [[Walter Oudney]], and [[Hugh Clapperton]] are the first Europeans to sight [[Lake Chad]].<ref name=Fleming>{{cite book | last = Fleming | first = Fergus | title = Barrow's Boys | publisher = Atlantic Monthly Press | year = 1998 | location = New York | page = }}</ref> *1823 – Sealer [[James Weddell]] sails to 74°15′ S into "King George IV's Sea" ([[Weddell Sea]]).<ref name=Weddell>{{cite book | last = Weddell | first = James | title = A voyage towards the South Pole, performed in the years 1822–'24. Containing ... a visit to Tierra del Fuego, with a particular account of the inhabitants. | publisher = Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green | year = 1825 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=tuIBAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=James+Weddell&hl=en&ei=tptNTMm8AYX0swP-__VI&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1824 – [[Samuel Black]] ascends the [[Finlay River|Finlay]] to [[Thutade Lake]], source of the Finlay-Peace-Slave-Mackenzie river system; then portages to the [[Stikine River|Stikine]] and [[Turnagain River|Turnagain]].<ref name=Hayes2002>{{cite book | last = Hayes | first = Derek | title = Historical Atlas of Canada: Canada’s History Illustrated with Original Maps | publisher = Douglas & McIntyre | year = 2002 | location = Vancouver | url = }}</ref> *1824–25 – [[Étienne Provost]], [[Jim Bridger]], and [[Peter Skene Ogden]] independently reach [[Great Salt Lake]].<ref name=Hayes/> *1825–26 – Franklin explores the Arctic coastline from the mouth of the Mackenzie River west to Point Beechey, while his partner [[John Richardson (naturalist)|John Richardson]] explores east to the Coppermine River, naming [[Dolphin and Union Strait]] and discovering "[[Wollaston Peninsula|Wollaston Land]]" (part of the southern coast of [[Victoria Island (Canada)|Victoria Island]]) — combining to chart over {{convert|1930|km|mi}} of coastline; Richardson also surveys the five arms of Great Bear Lake.<ref name=Franklin1828>{{cite book | last = Franklin | first = John | title = Narrative of a second expedition to the shores of the Polar sea in the years 1825, 1826 and 1827, by John Franklin,... including an account of the progress of a detachment to the Eastward, by John Richardson. | publisher = J. Murray | year = 1828 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=QOyb_rz5czIC&printsec=frontcover&dq=John+Franklin+1826&hl=en&ei=xl9QTM_zCIO8sQPn5MmOBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1826 – [[Frederick William Beechey]] charts the Alaskan coastline from Icy Cape to [[Point Barrow]]; also discovers [[Vanavana]], [[Fangataufa]], and [[Ahunui]] in the [[Tuamotu archipelago]].<ref name=Beechey>{{cite book | last = Beechey | first = Frederick William | title = Narrative of a voyage to the Pacific and Beering's Strait: to co-operate with the Polar expeditions : performed in His Majesty's Ship Blossom, under the command of Captain F.W. Beechey, R.N. ... in the years 1825,26,27,28. | publisher = Carey & Lea | year = 1832 | location = Philadelphia | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=7YcBAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA364&dq=Frederick+Beechey+1826&hl=en&ei=nqtYTMq_MYfSsAPLmKHuBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1826 – [[Alexander Gordon Laing]] becomes the first European to reach the fabled city of [[Timbuktu]].<ref name=Fleming/> *1827 – [[Jedediah Smith]] crosses the Sierra Nevada (via [[Ebbetts Pass]]) and [[Great Basin]].<ref name=Hayes/> *1828 – [[René Caillié]] is the first European to return alive from Timbuktu. *1829–30 – [[John Ross (Arctic explorer)|John Ross]] discovers "Boothia Felix" (the [[Boothia Peninsula]]); the following year his nephew [[James Clark Ross]] crosses its narrow [[isthmus]] and reaches [[King William Island]].<ref name=Edinger>{{cite book | last = Edinger | first = Ray | title = Fury Beach: The Four-year Odyssey of Captain John Ross and the Victory | publisher = Berkley Books | year = 2003 | location = New York}}</ref> *1830 – [[Richard Lemon Lander|Richard Lander]] and his brother [[John Lander (explorer)|John]] descend the [[Niger River|Niger]] for more than {{convert|643|km|mi}} from [[Bussa, Nigeria|Bussa]] to its mouth.<ref name=Fleming2004/> *1831–32 – [[John Biscoe]] discovers [[Enderby Land]]; following year discovers [[Adelaide Island|Adelaide]], [[Anvers Island|Anvers]], and [[Biscoe Islands]].<ref name=Mills/> *1833 – [[Andrei Glazunov]] and Semyon Lukin discover the mouth of the [[Yukon River]].<ref name=Hayes/> *1833–35 – [[Pyotr Pakhtusov]] and [[Avgust Tsivolko]] chart the entire east coast of [[Yuzhny Island]], as well as the east coast of [[Severny Island]] north to nearly 74°24’ N.<ref name=Mills/> *1834 – [[George Back]] descends the [[Back River (Nunavut)|Back River]] to [[Chantrey Inlet]].<ref name=Back>{{cite book | last = Back | first = George | title = Narrative of the Arctic land expedition to the mouth of the Great Fish River, and along the shores of the Arctic Ocean, in the years 1833, 1834 and 1835. | publisher = E.L. Carey & A. Hart | year = 1836 | location = Philadelphia | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Q8vhUiBdUXYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=George+Back+1836&hl=en&ei=T5FdTIy7IZKgsQO1-4WqCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1837 – Glazunov ascends the [[Unalakleet River|Unalakleet]] and portages to the middle Yukon.<ref name=Bockstoce>{{cite book | last = Bockstoce | first = John R. | title = Furs and Frontiers in the Far North: the Contest Among Native and Foreign Nations for the Bering Strait Fur Trade | publisher = Yale University Press | year = 2009 | location = New Haven | url = }}</ref> *1837–39 – [[Peter Warren Dease]] and [[Thomas Simpson (explorer)|Thomas Simpson]] reach [[Point Barrow]] from the east; following two summers they map the region from Point Turnagain to just north of the [[Castor and Pollux River]] on the Boothia Peninsula and chart the coastline of "Victoria Land" (Victoria Island) from Point Back to Point Parry.<ref name=Simpson>{{cite book | last = Simpson | first = Thomas | title = Narrative of the discoveries on the north coast of America: effected by the officers of the Hudson's Bay Company during the years 1836–39. | publisher = R. Bentley | year = 1843 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=CXBIAAAAMAAJ&pg=PR7&dq=Thomas+Simpson+1843&hl=en&ei=IFZkTJeBI46UnQeBk6WODw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1838 – Pyotr Malakhov reaches [[Nulato, Alaska|Nulato]], near the confluence of the [[Koyukuk River|Koyukuk]] and Yukon.<ref name=Bockstoce/> *1838–40 – [[Jules Dumont d'Urville]] discovers the [[Joinville Island group]] and [[Adélie Land]] (138°21′ E).<ref name=Mills/> *1839 – [[John Balleny]] discovers the [[Balleny Islands]] and sights the [[Sabrina Coast]] (121° E).<ref name=Mawar>{{cite book | last = Mawar | first = Granville Allen | title = Ahab's Trade: The Saga of South Seas Whaling. | publisher = St. Martin's Press | year = 1999 | location = New York | isbn=0-312-22809-0}}</ref> *1840 – [[Charles Wilkes]] discovers [[Wilkes Land]], mapping {{convert|2414|km|mi}} of the Antarctic coast from Piner Bay (140° E) to the [[Shackleton Ice Shelf]] (97° E), proving that [[Antarctica]] is a [[continent]].<ref name=Philbrick>{{cite book | last = Philbrick | first = Nathaniel | title = Sea of Glory: America's Voyage of Discovery, the U.S. Exploring Expedition, 1838–1842. | publisher = Viking | year = 2003 | location = New York | url = }}</ref> *1841–43 – James Clark Ross discovers the [[Ross Sea]], reaches 78°09′30″ S, and discovers the active volcano [[Mount Erebus]] on [[Ross Island]], the [[Ross Ice Shelf]], and [[Victoria Land]]; also sights [[Snow Hill Island|Snow Hill]], [[Seymour Island|Seymour]], and [[James Ross Island]]s.<ref name=Ross1843>{{cite book | last = Ross | first = James Clark | title = A voyage of discovery and research in the southern and Antarctic regions, during the years 1839–43. | publisher = John Murray | year = 1847 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=QDsNAAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=James%20Clark%20Ross%201847%20%20A%20Voyage%20of%20Discovery%20and%20Research%20to%20Southern%20and%20Antarctic%20Regions%20Vol.%201&source=gbs_book_other_versions#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1845 – [[John Bell (explorer)|John Bell]] discovers the [[Porcupine River|Porcupine]], which he descends to its confluence with the Yukon.<ref name=Bockstoce/> *1846 – Candido José da Costa Cardoso discovers [[Lake Malawi]].<ref name=Jeal1973/> *1846 – Rodrigues Graça travels from [[Angola (Portugal)|Angola]] to southwestern [[Katanga Plateau|Katanga]].<ref name=Jeal1973/> *1846–47 – [[John Rae (explorer)|John Rae]] maps over {{convert|1046|km|mi}} of coastline, from [[Lord Mayor Bay]] to Cape Crozier, discovering [[Committee Bay]].<ref name=McGoogan>{{cite book | last = McGoogan | first = Kenneth | title = Fatal passage: the true story of John Rae, the Arctic hero time forgot. | publisher = Carroll & Graf Publishers | year = 2003 | location = New York | url = }}</ref> *c. 1847–48 – [[António da Silva Porto]] reaches the upper [[Zambezi]].<ref name=Jeal1973/> *1848 – [[Johannes Rebmann]] is the first to sight [[Mount Kilimanjaro]].<ref name=Krapf>{{cite book | last = Krapf | first = J. L. | title = Travels, researches, and missionary labors during an eighteen years' residence in Eastern Africa together with journeys to Jagga, Usambara, Ukambani, Shoa, Abessinia and Khartum, and a coasting voyage from Mombaz to Cape Delgado | publisher = Ticknor and Fields | year = 1860 | location = Boston | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=mTE-AAAAcAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1849 – [[David Livingstone]] and [[William Cotton Oswell]] cross the [[Kalahari Desert]] to [[Lake Ngami]].<ref name=Jeal1973/> *1849 – James Clark Ross charts {{convert|240|km|mi}} of the west coast of Somerset Island south to Cape Coulman, discovering [[Peel Sound]].<ref name=Savours>{{cite book | last = Savours | first = Ann | title = The Search for the North West Passage | publisher = St. Marten's Press | year = 1999 | location = New York | url = }}</ref> *1850 – [[Edwin De Haven]] sails up [[Wellington Channel]], discovering and naming "Grinnell Land" (the [[Grinnell Peninsula]], which forms the northwestern corner of Devon Island).<ref name=Savours/> *1850–54 – [[Robert McClure]] transits the [[Northwest Passage]] (by boat and sledge); he and his men also chart some {{convert|2736|km|mi}} of new coastline, consisting of the entire coast of Banks Island and much of the northwestern coast of Victoria Island (from just east of Point Reynolds in the north to [[Prince Albert Sound]] in the south), in the process discovering [[Prince of Wales Strait]] and [[McClure Strait]].<ref>{{cite book |title=The Discovery of the North-West Passage |last=McClure |first=Robert|editor1-first=Sherard |editor1-last=Osborn |editor1-link=Sherard Osborn |year=1856 |publisher=Longman, Brown, Green, Longmans, & Roberts |location=London |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SGUZAAAAMAAJ&vq=the+discovery+of+the+north-west+passage&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s }}</ref><ref name=Armstrong1>{{cite book |title=A Personal Narrative of the Discovery of the Northwest Passage|last=Armstrong |first=Alexander |year=1857 |publisher=Hurst and Blackett |location=London |isbn= |page= |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=04dAAAAAYAAJ |accessdate=}}</ref> *1851 – Rae charts over {{convert|965|km|mi}} of the southern coastline of Victoria Island, from Cape Back to Pelly Point.<ref name=McGoogan/> *1851 – [[Erasmus Ommanney]], [[Sherard Osborn]] and William Browne chart the northern half of [[Prince of Wales Island (Nunavut)|Prince of Wales Island]], Osborn west to Sherard Osborn Point (72°20’ N) and Browne east to [[Pandora Island]]; meanwhile, Robert D. Aldrich charts the west coast of the Bathurst Island group north to Cape Aldrich (about 76°11’ N, on [[Île Vanier]]) and Dr. Abraham Bradford charts the east coast of Melville Island north to Bradford Point.<ref name=Mills/><ref name= Osborn1852>{{cite book | last = Osborn | first = Sherard | title = Stray leaves from an Arctic journal, or, Eighteen months in the polar regions : in search of Sir John Franklin's expedition, in the years 1850–51 | publisher = Putnam’s | year = 1852 | location = New York | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=6t8-AAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Sherard+Osborn&hl=en&ei=ZvFvTIbFCo30swP-jsH1Cg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1851 – [[Robert Campbell (fur trader)|Robert Campbell]] descends the [[Pelly River|Pelly]] to the Yukon, which he descends to its confluence with the Porcupine, reaching [[Fort Yukon, Alaska|Fort Yukon]].<ref name=Bockstoce/> *1851–52 – [[William Kennedy (explorer)|William Kennedy]] and [[Joseph René Bellot]] discover [[Bellot Strait]] and cross Prince of Wales Island east to west, reaching [[Ommanney Bay]].<ref name=Savours/> *1852 – [[Edward Augustus Inglefield]] reaches 78° 28’ N, entering Smith Sound; also charts Jones Sound as far west as 84° 10’ W.<ref name=Inglefield>{{cite book | last = Inglefield | first = E. A., George Dickie, and Peter C. Sutherland | title = A Summer Search for Sir John Franklin: with a Peep Into the Polar Basin | publisher = T. Harrison | year = 1853 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=3lAS8_tPLMYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=A+summer+search+for+Sir+John+Franklin%3B+with+a+peep+into+the+polar+basin&hl=en&ei=CD7PTNCvBJD0swPJ1JSkAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1852–53 – [[Edward Belcher]] sails two of his squadron to the northwestern coast of the Grinnell Peninsula, wintering at 77° 52’ N, 97° W; later circumnavigates the peninsula via Arthur Strait (now Fiord), discovering [[Cornwall Island (Nunavut)|Cornwall]] and [[North Kent Island|North Kent]].<ref name=Savours/> *1853 – [[Richard Vesey Hamilton]] and [[George Henry Richards]] chart the Sabine Peninsula of Melville Island from Cape Mudge east to Bradford Point; the latter, along with Sherard Osborn, also charts the northern coast of Bathurst Island.<ref name=Savours/><ref name=MDougall/> *1853 – [[George Mecham]] discovers [[Prince Patrick Island|Prince Patrick]] and [[Eglinton Island]]s and charts the southwest corner of Melville Island; along with [[Francis Leopold McClintock]], he charts nearly the entire coast of Prince Patrick; McClintock also charts the northwest coast of Melville Island, from Cape Fisher northwest to Cape Scott and south along its west coast to Cape Purchase.<ref name=MDougall>{{cite book | last = M'Dougall | first = George F. | title = The eventful voyage of H.M. discovery ship "Resolute" to the Arctic regions, in search of Sir John Franklin and the missing crews of H.M. discovery ships "Erebus" and "Terror," 1852, 1853, 1854 | publisher = Longman, Brown, Green, Longmans, & Roberts | year = 1857 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Bm4SAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA452&dq=The+Eventful+Voyages+of+HMS+Resolute&hl=en&ei=vDTCTOfmBYeqsAO0l5jPCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref><ref name=Murphy>{{cite book | last = Murphy | first = David | title = The Arctic Fox: Francis Leopold McClintock, discoverer of the fate of Franklin | publisher = Dundurn Press | year = 2004 | location = Toronto | url = }}</ref> *1853–54 – [[Elisha Kent Kane]] and his men chart the [[Kane Basin]] and discover [[Kennedy Channel]]; one of his men, William Morton, reaches as far north as Kap Constitution (81° 22’ N).<ref name=Kane>{{cite book | last = Kane | first = Elisha Kent | title = Arctic Explorations: The Second Grinnell Expedition in Search of Sir John Franklin, 1853, ’54, ’55 | publisher = S. C. Griggs & Co. | year = 1856 | location = Chicago | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=u9YBAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Elisha+Kent+Kane&hl=en&ei=7h7aTKGFMpL2tgOy292KCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1853–56 – Livingstone becomes the first to traverse Africa from west to east, traveling from [[Luanda]] in Angola to [[Quelimane]] in [[Mozambique]]; also explores much of the upper Zambezi and discovers and names [[Victoria Falls, Zambia|Victoria Falls]].<ref name=Jeal1973/> *1854 – Rae charts the Boothia Peninsula from the Castor and Pollux River north to Point de la Guiche, discovering [[Rae Strait]] and proving the insularity of King William Island.<ref name=McGoogan/> *1858 – [[Richard Francis Burton]] and [[John Hanning Speke]] discover [[Lake Tanganyika]] and [[Lake Victoria]].<ref name=Speke>{{cite book | last = Speke | first = John Hanning | title = What led to the discovery of the source of the Nile | publisher = Blackwood & Sons | year = 1864 | location = Edinburgh | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=KlAGAAAAQAAJ&pg=PP18&dq=John+Hanning+Speke+Lake+Tanganyika&hl=en&ei=QD66TO7ZCYP4sAP4n5S2Dw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEMQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1859 – McClintock charts the remaining {{convert|193|km|mi}} of the continental coastline of America (on the west coast of the Boothia Peninsula), while his companion [[Allen Young]] charts the southern half of Prince of Wales Island.<ref name=Savours/> *1860–61 – [[Robert O'Hara Burke]] and [[William John Wills|William Wills]] are the first to cross Australia from south to north, traveling from [[Melbourne]] to the [[Flinders River]].<ref name=Fleming2004/> *1862 – Speke discovers the Nile flowing from the northern end of Lake Victoria.<ref name=Fleming2004/> *1862 – Ivan Lukin ascends the Yukon to Fort Yukon.<ref name=Bockstoce/> *1864 – [[Samuel Baker]] discovers "Luta Nzige" ([[Lake Albert (Africa)|Lake Albert]]); in the distance he sights the [[Mountains of the Moon (Africa)|Mountains of the Moon]] (the [[Rwenzori Mountains|Rwenzori]]).<ref name=Fleming2004/> *1865 – [[Edward Whymper]] is the first to ascend the [[Matterhorn]].<ref name=Fleming2004/> *1869–70 – [[Carl Koldewey]] and [[Julius von Payer]] explore the east coast of Greenland from 74°18’ to 77°01’N.<ref name=Fleming2001>{{cite book|last=Fleming|first=Fergus|title= Ninety Degrees North: The Quest for the North Pole|publisher=Grove Press|year=2001|location=New York|url=}}</ref> *1871 – [[Charles Francis Hall]] reaches [[Robeson Channel]], sailing his ship as far north as 82° 11’ N; he later travels by sledge to 83° 05’ N.<ref name=Dick>{{cite book | last = Dick | first = Lyle | title = Muskox Land: Ellesmere Island in the Age of Contact | publisher = University of Calgary Press | year = 2001 | location = Calgary, Alta | url = }}</ref> *1872 – William Adams proves the insularity of Bylot Island.<ref name=Mills/> *1873–74 – [[Karl Weyprecht]] and Von Payer discover and name [[Franz Josef Land]].<ref name=Fleming2001/> *1875–76 – [[George Nares]] sails as far north as 82° 24’ N; following year [[Albert Hastings Markham]] sledges to 83° 20’ 26" N, while [[Pelham Aldrich]] sledges along the northern coast of Ellesmere Island east to Alert Point and '''Lewis A. Beaumont''' explores the northwestern coast of Greenland.<ref name=Dick/> *1875–77 – [[Henry Morton Stanley]] circumnavigates both Lakes Tanganyika and Victoria, sights [[Lake George (Uganda)|Lake George]], and descends the [[Lualaba River|Lualaba]] and [[Congo River|Congo]] to the sea.<ref name=Jeal>{{cite book | last = Jeal | first = Tim | title = Stanley: The Impossible Life of Africa’s Greatest Explorer | publisher = Yale University Press | year = 2007 | location = New Haven | url = }}</ref> *1876 – [[Luigi D'Albertis]] ascends over {{convert|800|km|mi}} up the [[Fly River]] in New Guinea.<ref name=Albertis>{{cite journal|author=D’Albertis, L. M. |year=1879|title=Journeys up the Fly River and in other parts of New Guinea|journal=Royal Geographical Society|volume=1|number=|pages=4–16}}</ref> *1878–79 – [[Adolf Erik Nordenskiöld]] is the first to transit the [[Northern Sea Route|Northeast Passage]].<ref name=Leslie1879>{{cite book | last = Leslie | first = Alexander | title = The Arctic Voyages of Adolf Erik Nordenskiöld. 1858–1879 | publisher = Macmillan and Co. | year = 1879 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=HrUvAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA343&dq=Adolf+Erik+Nordenski%C3%B6ld+Northeast+Passage+1878+1879&hl=en&ei=nssGTYDwMYbQsAOthtT3Bw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1881–83 – [[Adolphus Greely]] explores the interior of Ellesmere Island, discovering [[Lake Hazen]]; one of his men, [[James Booth Lockwood]], crosses the island and reaches [[Greely Fiord]], as well as sledging eastwards to the vicinity of Kap Washington (reaching 83° 23’08" N in the process).<ref name=Dick/> *1883–84 – [[Franz Boas]] is the first to see [[Nettilling Lake]].<ref name=Mills/> *1887–89 – Stanley traverses the [[Ituri Rainforest]], explores the Rwenzori, and follows the [[Semliki River|Semliki]] to its source (which he names [[Lake Edward]]).<ref name=Jeal/> *1892 – [[Robert Peary]] discovers and names [[Independence Fjord|Independence Bay]] and [[Peary Land]].<ref name=Fleming2001/> *1893–96 – [[Fridtjof Nansen]] and [[Hjalmar Johansen]] sledge to 86°13'06" N; their ship, the [[Fram]], under [[Otto Sverdrup]], drifts in the ice from the New Siberian Islands west to the northwest coast of Spitsbergen, reaching 85°55'05" N—a new record for a ship.<ref name=Fleming2001/> *1898–1902 – Sverdrup and [[Gunnar Isachsen]] chart the western coast of Ellesmere Island and discover and name [[Axel Heiberg Island|Axel Heiberg]], [[Ellef Ringnes Island|Ellef Ringnes]], [[Amund Ringnes Island|Amund Ringnes]], and [[King Christian Island]]s.<ref name=Sverdrup>{{cite book|last=Sverdrup|first=Otto and Ethel Harriet Hearn|title=New Land; Four Years in the Arctic Regions|publisher=Longmans, Green, and Co.|year=1904|location=London|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K0ENAQAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
==20th century== [[File:Aan de Zuidpool - p1913-160.jpg|thumb|Amundsen's party at the South Pole, December 1911. From left to right: [[Roald Amundsen|Amundsen]], [[Helmer Hanssen|Hanssen]], [[Sverre Hassel|Hassel]] and [[Oscar Wisting|Wisting]] (photo by fifth member [[Olav Bjaaland|Bjaaland)]].]] [[File:Scottgroup.jpg|right|thumb|alt= Five men in heavy clothing and headgear; three are standing and two seated on the ground. The standing men carry flags; all five have dejected expressions|Scott's party at the South Pole, 18 January 1912. L to R: (standing) [[Edward Adrian Wilson|Wilson]], [[Robert Falcon Scott|Scott]], [[Lawrence Oates|Oates]]; (seated) [[Henry Robertson Bowers|Bowers]], [[Edgar Evans]].]] [[File:Severnaya Zemlya - raising of the Russian flag in 1913.jpg|thumb|Severnaya Zemlya – raising of the Russian flag in 1913.]]
*1900 – Peary explores the north coast of Greenland from Kap Washington to Kap Clarence Wyckoff, on the way reaching [[Cape Morris Jesup]], the most northern point of mainland Greenland.<ref name=Mirsky>{{cite book|last=Mirsky|first=Jeannette|title=To the Arctic: The story of northern exploration from earliest times to the present|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=1970|location=Chicago|url=}}</ref> *1902–04 – [[Robert Falcon Scott]] traces the length of the Ross Ice Shelf, discovers the [[Edward VII Peninsula]], reaches about 82°11’ S (in the process tracing {{convert|600|km|mi}} of the west coast of the shelf), crosses the [[Transantarctic Mountains]] and discovers the [[Antarctic Plateau]], penetrating nearly {{convert|240|km|mi}} into it; he is also the first to see the [[McMurdo Dry Valleys|dry valleys]] of the [[Antarctic]].<ref name=Crane>{{cite book | last = Crane | first = David | title = Scott of the Antarctic: A Life of Courage and Tragedy | publisher = Alfred N. Knopf | year = 2006 | location = New York | url = }}</ref> *1903–06 – [[Roald Amundsen]] transits the Northwest Passage in the sloop ''[[Gjøa]]''; Godfred Hansen, his second-in-command, charts the east coast of Victoria Island north to Cape Nansen (72°02' N, 104°45' W).<ref name=Amundsen>{{cite book|last=Amundsen|first=Roald and Godfred Hansen|title=Roald Amundsen’s "The North West Passage"; being the record of a voyage of exploration of the ship "Gjøa" 1903–1907|publisher=A Constable and Co.|year=1908|location=London|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nwUZAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA27&dq=Roald+Amundsen's+North+West+Passage+1903+1907+Vol.+1&source=gbs_selected_pages&cad=3#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1906–07 – [[Ludvig Mylius-Erichsen]] and [[Johan Peter Koch]] chart the northeast coast of Greenland from Kap Bismarck (76°42' N) to Kap Clarence Wyckoff (82°52' N), discovering [[Danmark Fjord]].<ref name=Mills/> *1908–09 – [[Frederick Cook]] and Peary each claim to have reached the [[North Pole]]—the former is a fraud, the latter widely doubted.<ref name=Fleming2001/> *1910–11 – [[Bernhard Hantzsch]] crosses Baffin Island from Cumberland Sound to the [[Koukdjuak River]], exploring the west coast of the island north to 68°45’N.<ref name=Mills/> *1911–12 – Amundsen is the first to reach the [[South Pole]]; Scott and his team reach the Pole over a month later, all perishing on the return journey.<ref name=Crane/> *1913–14 – [[Boris Vilkitsky]] and Per Novopashennyy discover [[Severnaya Zemlya]], surveying parts of its eastern coast from [[Arctic Cape|Mys Arkticheskiy]] to Mys Vaygacha (its southeast point), as well as much of its south coast west to Mys Neupokoyeva.<ref name=Barr1975>{{cite journal|author=Barr, William |year=1975|title=Severnaya Zemlya: the last major discovery |journal=Geographical Journal|volume=141|number=1|pages=59–71|doi=10.2307/1796946}}</ref> *1915–17 – [[Vilhjalmur Stefansson]] discovers [[Brock Island|Brock]], [[Mackenzie King Island|Mackenzie King]], [[Borden Island|Borden]], [[Meighen Island|Meighen]], and [[Lougheed Island]]s; one of his men, Storker T. Storkerson, charts part of the northeast coast of Victoria Island, discovering the Storkerson Peninsula and [[Stefansson Island]].<ref name=Mills/><ref name=Stefansson>{{cite book | last = Stefansson | first = Vilhjalmur | title = The Friendly Arctic: The Story of Five Years in Polar Regions | publisher = Macmillan | year = 1922 | location = New York | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=BTUbAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1924–29 – [[J. Dewey Soper|Joseph Dewey Soper]] explores the interior of Baffin Island before surveying its west coast north to Hantzsch River.<ref name=Mills/> *1926 – Amundsen, [[Lincoln Ellsworth]] and [[Umberto Nobile]] in the airship [[Norge (airship)|Norge]] are the first definitely known to have sighted the North Pole.<ref name=Fleming2001/> *1927 – [[George P. Putnam]] charts the north coast of the Foxe Peninsula from Cape Dorchester to [[Bowman Bay, Nunavut|Bowman Bay]].<ref name=Mills/> *1930–32 – [[Georgy Ushakov]] and [[Nikolay Urvantsev]] survey the entire coast of Severnaya Zemlya, showing it to be made up of four main islands: [[October Revolution Island|October Revolution]], [[Komsomolets Island|Komsomolets]], [[Pioneer Island (Russia)|Pioneer]], and [[Bolshevik Island]]s—in all surveying some {{convert|2200|km|mi}} of coastline and interior.<ref name=Barr1975/> *1932 – W. A. Poole discovers [[Prince Charles Island]].<ref>Hayes, Derek. Newestfoundland (''Canadian Geographic'', October -November 2003 issue).</ref> *1934 – [[Richard E. Byrd]] discovers and names [[Roosevelt Island, Antarctica|Roosevelt Island]]. *1937–41 – [[Thomas Henry Manning|Thomas and Ella Manning]] map the west coast of Baffin Island from the Hantzsch River to [[Steensby Inlet]].<ref name=Mills/> *1940 – Byrd discovers [[Thurston Island]], believing it to be a peninsula. *1948 – E. C. Kerslake charts Prince Charles, [[Air Force Island|Air Force]], and [[Foley Island]]s.<ref name=Hayes/> *1950 – [[Maurice Herzog]] and [[Louis Lachenal]] of the [[1950 French Annapurna expedition|French Annapurna expedition]] become the first climbers to reach the summit of an [[Eight-thousander|8,000-metre]] peak.<ref name=Herzog1997>{{cite book | last = Herzog | first = Maurice | title = Annapurna, first conquest of an 8000-meter peak (26,493 feet) | publisher = Lyons & Burford | year = 1997 | location = New York | url = }}</ref> *1953 – [[Edmund Hillary]] and [[Tenzing Norgay]] are the first to ascend [[Mount Everest]].<ref name="HighAdventure">Hillary, Edmund (1955). ''High Adventure: The True Story of the First Ascent of Everest''. Hodder & Stoughton, London.</ref> *1954 – [[Lino Lacedelli]] and [[Achille Compagnoni]] are the first to ascend [[K2]].<ref>{{cite book |title=K2: The Story of the Savage Mountain|last=Curran|first=Jim|authorlink=|year=1995 |publisher=Hodder & Stoughton|location= |isbn=978-0-340-66007-2|page=}}</ref> *1957 – [[Finn Ronne]] discovers [[Berkner Island]].
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=24em}}
{{Exploration}}
