page.title: United States Board on Geographic Names

revision.text:
{{Infobox government agency | name = United States Board on Geographic Names | type = Board | seal = United States Board on Geographic Names logo.png | seal_width = | seal_caption = | logo = | logo_width = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_caption = | formed = {{start date and age|1890|09|04}} | preceding1 = | preceding2 = <!-- up to |preceding6= --> | dissolved = | superseding1 = | superseding2 = <!-- up to |superseding6= --> | jurisdiction = | headquarters = | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LATITUDE|LONGITUDE|type:landmark_region:US|display=inline,title}} --> | motto = | employees = | budget = | minister1_name = | minister1_pfo = | minister2_name = | minister2_pfo = <!-- up to |minister8_name= --> | deputyminister1_name = | deputyminister1_pfo = | deputyminister2_name = | deputyminister2_pfo = <!-- up to |deputyminister8_name= --> | chief1_name = Leo Dillon | chief1_position = Chair | chief2_name = | chief2_position = <!-- up to |chief9_name= --> | public_protector = | deputy = | parent_department = | parent_agency = | child1_agency = | child2_agency = <!-- up to |child25_agency= --> | keydocument1 = <!-- up to |keydocument6= --> | website = {{official URL}} | agency_id = | map = | map_size = | map_caption = | footnotes = | embed = }} The '''United States Board on Geographic Names''' ('''BGN''') is a [[Federal government of the United States|federal]] body operating under the [[United States Secretary of the Interior]]. The purpose of the board is to establish and maintain uniform usage of [[geography|geographic]] names throughout the [[federal government of the United States]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://geonames.usgs.gov/publications/docs/November2016_updates/BGN%20Getting%20the%20Facts%20Straight.pdf | publisher=United States Board on Geographic Names | title=The United States Board on Geographic Names: Getting the Facts Straight | date=November 2016 | access-date=18 December 2017}}</ref>
==Overview== The board was created in 1890 by [[executive order (United States)|executive order]];<ref name="eo28">{{cite executive order |number = 28 |url = |date = 1890-09-04|language = English |post = President of the United States of America |accessdate = {{date|2017-07-16|dmy}} }}{{wikisource-inline|Executive Order 28|single=true}}</ref> its present form derives from a law of 1947.
{{Wikisource|1=Executive Order 28}} On January 8, 1890, [[Thomas Corwin Mendenhall|T. C. Mendenhall]], superintendent of the [[US Coast and Geodetic Survey]] Office, wrote to 10 noted geographers "to suggest the organization of a Board made up of representatives from the different Government services interested, to which may be referred any disputed question of geographical orthography."<ref name=":0" /> President [[Benjamin Harrison]] signed Executive Order 28 on September 4, 1890, establishing the United States Board on Geographic Names.<ref name="eo28"/> "To this Board shall be referred all unsettled questions concerning geographic names. The decisions of the Board are to be accepted [by federal departments] as the standard authority for such matters."<ref name=":0" /><ref name="eo28"/> The board was given authority to resolve all unsettled questions concerning geographic names. Decisions of the board were accepted as binding by all departments and agencies of the [[federal government of the United States|federal government]].
The board has developed principles, policies, and procedures governing the use of domestic and foreign geographic names. It also deals with the names of geographical features underseas<ref name=ACUF>[http://earth-info.nga.mil/gns/html/acuf.html "Advisory Committee on Undersea Features"] Accessed 2013-10-18.</ref> and in [[Antarctica]].
Although its official purpose is to resolve name problems and new name proposals for the federal government, the board also plays a similar role for the general public. Any person or organization, public or private, may make inquiries or request the board to render formal decisions on proposed new names, proposed name changes, or names that are in conflict. Generally, the BGN defers federal name use to comply with local usage. There are a few exceptions. For example, in rare cases where a locally used name is very offensive, the BGN may decide against adoption of the local name for federal use.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://geonames.usgs.gov/docs/pro_pol_pro.pdf| title=Principles, Policies, and Procedures| author=Donald J. Orth and Roger L. Payne| publisher=United States Board on Geographic Names and Domestic Geographic Names| year=2003| accessdate=July 7, 2009| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108233358/http://geonames.usgs.gov/docs/pro_pol_pro.pdf| archivedate=January 8, 2016| df=}}</ref>
In federal mapping and names collection efforts, there is often a phase lag where a delay occurs in adoption of a locally used name. Sometimes the delay is several decades. Volunteers in the Earth Science Corps are used to assist the US Geological Survey in collecting names of geographic features.
The [[Geographic Names Information System]], developed by the BGN in cooperation with the US Geological Survey, includes topographic map names and bibliographic references. The names of books and historic maps which confirm the feature or place name are cited. Variant names, alternatives to official federal names for a feature, are also recorded.
The BGN has members from six federal departments as well as the [[Central Intelligence Agency]], the [[Government Publishing Office]], the [[Library of Congress]], and the [[US Postal Service]]. The BGN rules on hundreds of naming decisions annually and stores over two million geographical records in its databases at geonames.usgs.gov. State and local governments, and private mapping organizations usually follow the BGN's decisions.
The BGN has an executive committee and two permanent committees with full authority: the 10- to 15-member Domestic Names Committee and the 8- to 10-member Foreign Names Committee. Both comprise government employees only. Each maintains its own database.<ref name=":0" />
The BGN does not create a place name, the BGN responds to proposals for names from federal agencies; state, local, and tribal governments; and the public. The BGN does not translate terms, but instead accurately uses foreign names in the Roman alphabet. For non-Roman languages, the BGN uses transliteration systems or creates them for less well-known languages.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Who Decides What Names Go on a Map?|url = http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2015/09/150918-us-board-geographical-names-125th-anniversary-national-geographic-maps-place-names/|website = National Geographic News|accessdate = 2015-09-19|first = Jeremy|last = Berlin|first2 = National Geographic PUBLISHED September|last2 = 18}}</ref>
==Publications== The BGN currently publishes names on its website. In the past, the BGN issued its decisions in various publications under different titles at different intervals with various information included.<ref name=Topping/> In 1933, the BGN published a significant consolidated report of all decisions from 1890 to 1932 in its ''Sixth Report of the United States Geographic Board 1890–1932''.<ref name=Topping/> For many years, the BGN published a quarterly report under the title ''Decisions on Geographic Names''.<ref name=Topping/>
==History== The BGN was established in 1890 as the ''Board on Geographical<!-- "Geographical" is correct for the original name --> Names'' and has undergone several name changes.<ref name=Topping>Topping, Mary, comp., ''Approved Place Names in Virginia: An Index to Virginia Names Approved by the United States Board on Geographic Names through 1969'' (Charlottesville, VA: University Press of Virginia, 1971), v–vi.</ref> In 1934, it was transferred to the Department of the Interior.<ref name=Topping/> The 1969 BGN publication ''Decisions on Geographic Names in the United States'' stated the agency's chief purpose as:
{{quote|[Names are] submitted for decisions to the Board on Geographical names by individuals, private organizations, or government agencies. It is the Board's responsibility to render formal decisions on new names, proposed changes in names, and names which are in conflict. [The decisions] define the spellings and applications of the names for use on maps and other publications of Federal agencies<ref name=Topping/>}}
In 1963, the Advisory Committee on Undersea Features was started for a standardization of names of undersea features.<ref name=ACUF/>
== Other authorities == * The [[United States Census Bureau]] defines [[census designated place]]s, which are a subset of locations in the Geographic Names Information System. * The names of post offices have historically been used to back up claims about the name of a community. US Postal Service Publication 28 gives standards for addressing mail. In this publication, the [[United States Postal Service|Postal Service]] defines two-letter state abbreviations, street identifiers such as ''boulevard'' (''BLVD'') and ''street'' (''ST''), and secondary identifiers such as ''suite'' (''STE'').
==See also== {{Portal|Geography|Government of the United States}} * [[BGN/PCGN romanization]], a system for rendering geographic names in other writing systems into the Latin alphabet * [[Composite Gazetteer of Antarctica]] * [[Denali–Mount McKinley naming dispute]] * [[Henry Gannett]], "Father of the Quadrangle Map" * [[Geographical Names Board of Canada]] * [[Geographical Names Board of New South Wales]]
==References== ===Footnotes=== {{reflist}}
===Bibliography=== *U.S. Department of the Interior, U.S. Geological Survey, National Mapping Division, ''Digital Gazetteer: Users Manual'', (Reston, Virginia: U.S. Geological Survey, 1994). *Report: "Countries, Dependencies, Areas Of Special Sovereignty, And Their Principal Administrative Divisions", Federal Information Processing Standards, FIPS 10-4. *Report: "Principles, Policies, and Procedures: Domestic Geographic Names", U.S. Board of Geographic Names, 1997. *''U.S. Postal Service Publication 28'', November 2000.
==External links== * {{Official website}}
[[Category:Names of places in Antarctica]] [[Category:Agencies of the United States government|Board on Geographic Names]] [[Category:Geography of the United States|Board on Geographic Names]] [[Category:Geocodes]] [[Category:Toponymy]] [[Category:United States Department of the Interior|Board on Geographic Names]] [[Category:United States Geological Survey|Board on Geographic Names]] [[Category:1890 establishments in the United States]]

revision.comment: /* WA/SA border marking history */ wrong link
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2012}} {{cleanup|reason=Tone and formatting|date=February 2012}} [[File:WesternAustraliaMap.png|thumb|Western Australia highlighted within Australia.]] The '''Western Australian border''' was originally designated as [[129th meridian east]] [[longitude]] (129° east). However, the border marked on the ground is some distance from this line.{{cite conference | title=An Historical Perspective – Longitude 129 degrees east, and why it is not the longest, straight line in the world | publisher=Eyepiece – Official Organ of The Institution of Surveyors, Australia, W.A. Division | accessdate=15 January 2012 | author=Porter, John, Surveyor-General of South Australia |date=April 1990 | conference=National Perspectives – 32nd Australian Surveyors Congress Technical Papers 31 March – 6 April 1990 | location=Canberra: The Institution | pages=18–24 | publicationdate=June 1990}} [[Kununurra]] is the closest town to the Western Australian border, being about 25 km west of the border. The closest settlement is [[Border Village]], 1,734 km to the south on the South Australian side of the border, on [[Eyre Highway]]. ==Border delineation== The Western Australian (WA) border marked on the ground, is not as straight as it looks on a map. The [[Northern Territory borders|Northern Territory border]] with Western Australia and the [[South Australian borders|South Australian border]] with Western Australia are displaced east–west by approximately 127 metres, due to errors within the limits of surveying technology available in the 1920s. Where Western Australia meets the [[Northern Territory]] (NT) and [[South Australia]] (SA) borders is a 127-metre segment running east–west along the [[26th parallel south]] [[latitude]] (26° south). In June 1968, two monuments were erected to mark each end of this 127-metre segment, At the easternmost of these concrete [[Boundary marker|border markers]] all three borders meet, at [[Surveyor Generals Corner]]. ==History== [[File:Australia history.gif|right|thumb|250px|Map showing the creation of the colonies/states and mainland territories.]] ===1788–1825=== In 1788 [[Arthur Phillip|Governor Phillip]] claimed the continent of Australia only as far west as the [[135th meridian east]] (135° east) in accordance with his commission.{{cite web | url = http://www.foundingdocs.gov.au/item.asp?dID=35 | title = Governor Phillip's Instructions 25 April 1787 (UK) | work = Documenting a Democracy | publisher = [[National Archives of Australia]] | accessdate = 2006-05-28 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060615195616/http://foundingdocs.gov.au/item.asp?dID=35 | archivedate = 15 June 2006 | df = dmy-all }} ([[Territorial evolution of Australia#26 January 1788|26 January 1788 – MAP]]) It has been suggested that the 1788 claim by the British of 135° east was in reference to [[Spanish Empire|Spain's]] claims under the [[Treaty of Tordesillas]]. Spain was seen as no longer having an interest in the area. On the other hand, the other signatories to the treaty, the [[Portuguese Empire|Portuguese]] still had a presence in [[Macau]] and [[East Timor]]. Adoption of 135° east as a boundary would minimise provocation of the Portuguese. By 1825, however, Britain was powerful enough and found it convenient to adopt the original line of the Portuguese under the treaty, 129° east.{{cite web |last = Brown |first = A. J. |year = 2003| url = http://www4.gu.edu.au:8080/adt-root/uploads/approved/adt-QGU20041105.092443/public/03Chapter2.pdf| title = Chapter two: Union or unity? Anglo-Australian territorial theory to the 1840s| format = pdf | work = The Frozen Continent: The fall and rise of territory in Australian constitutional thought 1815-2003. PhD Thesis]) | publisher = Griffith University| accessdate = 2006-05-28}} ===1825–29=== The line of 129° east first became a border in Australia as the western border of [[New South Wales]] (NSW) in 1825 ([[Territorial evolution of Australia#16 July 1825|16 July 1825 – MAP]]). On 16 July [[1825 in Australia|1825]], the western boundary of New South Wales was relocated at 129° east to take in the new settlement at [[Melville Island, Northern Territory|Melville Island]].{{cite book | last = Taylor | first = Peter | authorlink = | year = 1990 | title = The Atlas of Australian History | publisher = Child & Associates Publishing Pty Ltd | location = Sydney, New South Wales, Australia | isbn = 0-86777-429-0 | pages = 118–9 | chapter = Chapter 10: Government and the States}} From 1825 to 1829 129° east was the NSW border, except that the settlement of [[King George's Sound]], now [[Albany, Western Australia|Albany]], was part of New South Wales from its establishment on 26 December 1826, until 7 March 1831 when it was made part of the Swan River Colony.{{cite web |url=http://search.records.nsw.gov.au/agencies/2517;jsessionid=A40C0DC3DCADFDD2F844802E811AA62B |title=King George's Sound Settlement |work=State Records |publisher=[[State Records Authority of New South Wales]] |accessdate=14 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517120618/http://search.records.nsw.gov.au/agencies/2517%3Bjsessionid%3DA40C0DC3DCADFDD2F844802E811AA62B |archivedate=17 May 2014 |df=dmy-all }} ===1829–32=== Following the settlement of the [[Swan River Colony]] (SRC) in [[1829 in Australia|1829]] ([[Territorial evolution of Australia#2 May 1829|2 May 1829 – MAP]]), the eastern boundary was declared to be 129° east, that is coinciding with the western boundary of New South Wales at the time.{{cite web | url = http://www.foundingdocs.gov.au/resources/transcripts/wa5i_doc_1831.pdf | title = Transcript of Commission appointing Stirling Governor and Commander-in-Chief 4 March 1831 (UK) | format = pdf| work = Documenting a Democracy | publisher = [[National Archives of Australia]] | accessdate = 2006-05-28}} The Swan River Colony, started in 1829, was commissioned as the colony of Western Australia in March [[1831 in Australia|1831]].{{cite web | url = http://www.foundingdocs.gov.au/item.asp?dID=94 | title = Commission appointing Stirling Governor and Commander-in-Chief 4 March 1831 (UK) | work = Documenting a Democracy | publisher = [[National Archives of Australia]] | accessdate = 2006-05-28 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080207042047/http://www.foundingdocs.gov.au/item.asp?dID=94 | archivedate = 7 February 2008 | df = dmy-all }} found cited in [[Territorial evolution of Australia#6 February 1832|Territorial evolution of Australia – 6 February 1832]] From 1829 to 1832 129° east was the SRC/NSW border. ===1832–46=== The name of the Swan River Colony changed to Western Australia in 1832 ([[Territorial evolution of Australia#6 February 1832|6 February 1832 – MAP]]).Cited in [[Territorial evolution of Australia#6 February 1832|Territorial evolution of Australia – 6 February 1832]] From 1832 to 1846 129° east was the WA/NSW border. ===1846–47=== In 1846 the colony of North Australia (NA) was proclaimed by Letters Patent, which was all of New South Wales north of 26° south. ([[Territorial evolution of Australia#17 February 1846|17 February 1846 – Map]]).Cited in [[Territorial evolution of Australia#17 February 1846|Territorial evolution of Australia – 17 February 1846]] From 1846 to 1847 129° east was the WA/NA border north of 26° south and the WA/NSW border south of the 26th parallel. ===1847–60=== In 1847 the colony of North Australia was revoked and reincorporated into New South Wales. ([[Territorial evolution of Australia#15 April 1847|15 April 1847 – MAP]]).Cited in [[Territorial evolution of Australia#15 April 1847|Territorial evolution of Australia – 15 April 1847]] From 1847 to 1860 129° east was once again the WA/NSW border. ===1860–63=== In 1860 South Australia, which had been proclaimed a colony in 1836 ([[Territorial evolution of Australia#28 December 1836|28 December 1836 – MAP]]), west to the [[132nd meridian east|132° east]], changed their western border from 132° east to 129° east ([[Territorial evolution of Australia#1860|1860 – MAP]]).Cited in [[Territorial evolution of Australia#1860|Territorial evolution of Australia – 1860]] From 1860 to 1863 129° east was the WA/NSW border north of 26° south and the WA/SA border south of the 26th parallel. ===1863–1911=== In 1863 that part of New South Wales to the north of South Australia was annexed to South Australia by Letters Patent and became known as the Northern Territory of South Australia (NToSA). ([[Territorial evolution of Australia#6 July 1863|6 July 1863 – MAP]]).Cited in [[Territorial evolution of Australia#6 July 1863|Territorial evolution of Australia – 6 July 1863]] From 1863 to 1911 129° east was the WA/NToSA border north of 26° south and the WA/SA border south of the 26th parallel ===1911–27=== In 1911 the [[Northern Territory]] (NT) was split off from South Australia to be administered by the Commonwealth. ([[Territorial evolution of Australia#1 January 1911|1 January 1911 – MAP]]).Cited in [[Territorial evolution of Australia#1 January 1911|Territorial evolution of Australia – 1 January 1911]] From 1911 to 1927 129° east was the WA/NT border north of 26° south and the WA/SA border south of the 26th parallel. ===1927–31=== In 1927 the Northern Territory was split into two territories, [[North Australia (territory)|North Australia]] (NA) and [[Central Australia (territory)|Central Australia]] (CA). ([[Territorial evolution of Australia#1 March 1927|1 March 1927 – MAP]]).Cited in [[Territorial evolution of Australia#1 March 1927|Territorial evolution of Australia – 1 March 1927]] From 1927 to 1931 129° east was once again the WA/NA border and WA/CA border, both north of 26° south and the WA/SA border south of the 26th parallel. ===1931–present=== In 1931 North Australia and Central Australia were reunited as the Northern Territory. ([[Territorial evolution of Australia#12 June 1931|12 June 1931 – MAP]]).Cited in [[Territorial evolution of Australia#12 June 1931|Territorial evolution of Australia – 12 June 1931]] From 1931 to the present 129° east has been the WA/NT border north of 26° south and the WA/SA border south of the 26th parallel. ==Marking the WA border on the ground== ===History of fixing the border=== Fixing the position of the border of Western Australia on the ground has a rich history. In March 1920 the [[Western Australian Government Astronomer]], [[H. B. Curlewis]] gave a talk at the WA Museum about the history of the determination of [[longitude]], in relation to using what was at that time a new technology, by using [[Time signal#Electrical time signals|wireless time signals]] to determine the position of the border between South Australia and Western Australia, as close to the 129th east meridian as possible. {{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27677780 |title=ROYAL SOCIETY. |newspaper=[[The West Australian]] |location=Perth |date=17 March 1920 |accessdate=9 January 2012 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} ====WA/SA border marking history==== Preliminary work on the border determinations began in November [[1920 in Australia|1920]] when the [[South Australian Government Astronomer|Government Astronomer]] for South Australia, G.F. Dodwell and the Government Astronomer of Western Australia, H.B. Curlewis met at [[Deakin, Western Australia]] on the [[Trans-Australian Railway|East-West Trans-Australian Railway]]. {{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article73353345 |title=FIXING A BOUNDARY. |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=6 December 1920 |accessdate=9 January 2012 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}
The other members of the party were Messrs. [[Clive Melville Hambidge]] and J. Crabb, of the Survey Department; Warrant Officer V. D. Bowen, in charge of wireless apparatus lent by the Defence Department; and Mr. C. A. Maddern, of the [[Adelaide Observatory]], all from Adelaide.
Concrete piers for the astronomical observing instruments were erected in readiness for the final determinations that were to be held in 1921. Observations were made for the purpose of testing under field conditions the instruments and methods to be used in 1921. This expedition, to determine 129° east on the ground, created worldwide scientific interest and involved the cooperation of the [[Astronomer Royal]] and the [[Royal Observatory, Greenwich]], with [[Time signal#Electrical time signals|wireless time signals]] sent by the French wireless Service, that were transmitted from the [[:fr:Observatoire de Lyon|Lyons astronomical observatory (Observatoire de Lyon)]] at [[Saint-Genis-Laval]], near [[Lyon, France|Lyons, France]], between 17 and 24 November 1920. Wireless time signals were also sent from the Adelaide Observatory, transmitted by the Adelaide Radio Station, to enable the beats of the Adelaide sidereal clock to be used as a control on the rate of the chronometer used for the boundary observation. After these initial tests a comprehensive program was then arranged for the second stage of the border determinations, which were to take place during the following year and dates were then set for that to happen, from 20 April to 10 May 1921. =====Deakin Pillar===== One of the concrete piers mentioned, which were cubic concrete blocks slightly smaller than a cubic metre, would later be named as the Deakin Pillar (1921), being from where the larger border marker, the Deakin [[Obelisk]] (1926), would be set out from. =====Deakin Obelisk===== The Deakin Pillar is approximately 2.82 km west of the Deakin Obelisk. The Deakin Obelisk was erected as closely as was possible with the technology of [[1926 in Australia|1926]] to 129° east. The Deakin Obelisk has a copper plug embedded into the top centre of the concrete obelisk, which determines, on the ground, the South Australian border with Western Australia by a line drawn south to the coastline of the [[Great Australian Bight]] and north through this point to 26° south. ====WA/NT border marking history==== Shortly after the [[1921 in Australia|1921]] determinations of the border of South Australia and Western Australia, the Government Astronomer for South Australia, G.F. Dodwell and the Government Astronomer of Western Australia, H.B. Curlewis and party travelled by the [[State Shipping Service of Western Australia|State Ship]] Bambra to the port of [[Wyndham, Western Australia]]. {{cite web |url=http://www.kununurra.org.au/research/1921-wa-nt-border-determinations |title=1921 WA-NT Border Determinations |accessdate=9 January 2012 |publisher=Kununurra Historical Society Inc.}} From Wyndham they were guided by [[Michael Durack|Michael Patrick ("M.P.") Durack]] to a point he perceived as the northern boundary between his [[Argyle Downs]] Station and Jack Kilfoyle's Rosewood Station, which was also Western Australia's border with the Northern Territory or 129° east. Most of Rosewood station is in the Northern Territory but some distance further south Rosewood also extends into the East Kimberley Region of Western Australia. From the chosen position, two concrete pillars were erected similar to those described above and portable radio masts set up, before the determinations were carried out by the scientists using the same methods of wireless time signals as were used at Deakin. =====Austral Pillar===== One of the concrete pillars erected, which was the one used as the point of the determinations, was marked by the expedition party to show how far east of Greenwich they were in hours, minutes and seconds, and became known as the Austral Pillar. The Austral Pillar, the point selected for the scientific determinations of 1921 would later be found to be about 2 km east from the border of 129° east on that part of Rosewood Station, therefore inside the Northern Territory. =====Kimberley Obelisk===== The Kimberley Obelisk was erected as closely as was possible with the technology of 1927 to 129° east. Over several weeks during [[1927 in Australia|1927]], a Western Australian [[Surveying|survey]] crew from the WA [[Department of Lands and Surveys, Western Australia|Department of Lands and Surveys]] travelled to Wyndham, then to the Austral Pillar site to set out from that point to the border, where they then erected the much more substantial Kimberley Obelisk. The Kimberley Obelisk has a copper plug embedded into the top of the concrete obelisk, which officially determines the WA/NT border on the ground, near 129° east, by a line drawn north to the northern coastline near the [[Joseph Bonaparte Gulf]] and south through this point at the Kimberley Obelisk to the 26th parallel. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==See also== * [[South Australia-Victoria border dispute]] * [[Greenwich Time Signal]] * [[Surveyor General]] * [[Surveyor General of Western Australia]] [[Category:Borders of Australia]] [[Category:Borders of Western Australia]] [[Category:Borders of New South Wales]] [[Category:Borders of South Australia]] [[Category:Geography of the Northern Territory]] [[Category:History of Western Australia]] [[Category:History of South Australia]] [[Category:History of New South Wales]] [[Category:History of the Northern Territory]] [[Category:Surveying]] [[Category:Boundary markers]]
